<li><a href="/wiki/Uparati" title="Uparati">Uparati (self-settledness)</a></li>

<li><a href="/wiki/Ahamkara" title="Ahamkara">Ahamkara (attachment)</a></li></ul>

<li><i><a href="/wiki/Vinayagar_Agaval" title="Vinayagar Agaval">Vinayagar Agaval</a></i></li></ul></div></div></td>
</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content plainlist">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="border:1px solid #FFC569;background:#FFC569;padding-top:0.1em;padding-left:3em; text-align:center;">Society</div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content hlist" style="text-align:center;padding-top:0; background-color:#FDE7B9; border:2px solid #FDE7B9">
<dl><dt><div style="font-size: 100%; background-color:#ffd6ad; border-top:0px dashed"><a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">Varna</a></div></dt></dl>
<dl><dd><i>Four varnas:</i></dd></dl>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmana</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kshatriya" title="Kshatriya">Kshatriya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vaishya" title="Vaishya">Vaishya</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shudra" title="Shudra">Shudra</a></li></ul>
<dl><dd><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Avarna" title="Avarna">Varna-less</a>:</i></dd></dl>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Dalit" title="Dalit">Dalit</a></li></ul>
<dl><dd><i>Varna-related topics:</i></dd></dl>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/J%C4%81ti" title="Jāti">Jati</a></li></ul>
<dl><dt><div style="font-size: 100%; background-color:#ffd6ad; border-top:0px dashed">Other society-related topics:</div></dt></dl>

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-content plainlist">
<div class="sidebar-list mw-collapsible mw-collapsed"><div class="sidebar-list-title" style="border:1px solid #FFC569;background:#FFC569;padding-top:0.1em;padding-left:3em; text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Portal:Hinduism" title="Portal:Hinduism">Other topics</a></div><div class="sidebar-list-content mw-collapsible-content hlist" style="text-align:center;padding-top:0; background-color:#FDE7B9; border:2px solid #FDE7B9">

</tr><tr><td class="sidebar-below hlist">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Glossary_of_Hinduism_terms" title="Glossary of Hinduism terms">Glossary</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Outline_of_Hinduism" title="Outline of Hinduism">Outline</a></li></ul>
<ul><li><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="367" data-file-width="356" decoding="async" height="16" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/16px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/23px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/67/Aum_Om_red.svg/31px-Aum_Om_red.svg.png 2x" width="16"/> <a href="/wiki/Portal:Hinduism" title="Portal:Hinduism">Hinduism portal</a></li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="sidebar-navbar"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1063604349">.mw-parser-output .navbar{display:inline;font-size:88%;font-weight:normal}.mw-parser-output .navbar-collapse{float:left;text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .navbar-boxtext{word-spacing:0}.mw-parser-output .navbar ul{display:inline-block;white-space:nowrap;line-height:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::before{margin-right:-0.125em;content:"[ "}.mw-parser-output .navbar-brackets::after{margin-left:-0.125em;content:" ]"}.mw-parser-output .navbar li{word-spacing:-0.125em}.mw-parser-output .navbar a>span,.mw-parser-output .navbar a>abbr{text-decoration:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-mini abbr{font-variant:small-caps;border-bottom:none;text-decoration:none;cursor:inherit}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-full{font-size:114%;margin:0 7em}.mw-parser-output .navbar-ct-mini{font-size:114%;margin:0 4em}</style><div class="navbar plainlinks hlist navbar-mini"><ul><li class="nv-view"><a href="/wiki/Template:Hinduism" title="Template:Hinduism"><abbr title="View this template">v</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-talk"><a href="/wiki/Template_talk:Hinduism" title="Template talk:Hinduism"><abbr title="Discuss this template">t</abbr></a></li><li class="nv-edit"><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Template:Hinduism&amp;action=edit"><abbr title="Edit this template">e</abbr></a></li></ul></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>Hinduism</b> (<span class="rt-commentedText nowrap"><span class="IPA nopopups noexcerpt" lang="en-fonipa"><a href="/wiki/Help:IPA/English" title="Help:IPA/English">/<span style="border-bottom:1px dotted"><span title="/ˈ/: primary stress follows">ˈ</span><span title="'h' in 'hi'">h</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'n' in 'nigh'">n</span><span title="'d' in 'dye'">d</span><span title="/u/: 'u' in 'influence'">u</span><span title="/ɪ/: 'i' in 'kit'">ɪ</span><span title="'z' in 'zoom'">z</span><span title="/əm/: 'm' in 'rhythm'">əm</span></span>/</a></span></span>)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-1"><a href="#cite_note-1">[1]</a></sup> is variously defined as an <a href="/wiki/Indian_religions" title="Indian religions">Indian religion</a>, a set of religious beliefs or practices, a religious tradition, a way of life, or <i><a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">dharma</a></i>—a religious and universal order by which followers abide.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-definition_2-0"><a href="#cite_note-definition-2">[note 1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-dharma_3-0"><a href="#cite_note-dharma-3">[note 2]</a></sup> As a religion it is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's third-largest</a>, with over 1.2–1.35 billion followers, or 15–16% of the global population, known as <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">Hindus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-4"><a href="#cite_note-4">[2]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-5"><a href="#cite_note-5">[3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pewforum_Hinduism_6-0"><a href="#cite_note-pewforum_Hinduism-6">[web 1]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-gordonconwell.edu_7-0"><a href="#cite_note-gordonconwell.edu-7">[web 2]</a></sup> The word <i>Hindu</i> is an <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Exonym" title="Exonym">exonym</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESiemensRoodt2009546_8-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESiemensRoodt2009546-8">[4]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELeaf201436_9-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELeaf201436-9">[5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_term_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_term-10">[note 3]</a></sup> and while Hinduism has been called the oldest religion in the world,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-oldest_religion_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-oldest_religion-11">[note 4]</a></sup> many practitioners refer to their religion as <i><a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tana_Dharma" title="Sanātana Dharma">Sanātana Dharma</a></i> (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a>: <span lang="sa">सनातन धर्म</span>, <small><a href="/wiki/Literal_translation" title="Literal translation">lit.</a> </small>''the Eternal Dharma''), a modern usage, which refers to the idea that its origins lie beyond human history, as revealed in the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">Hindu texts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnott19983,_5_12-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnott19983,_5-12">[6]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHatcher20154–5,_69–71,_150–152_13-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHatcher20154–5,_69–71,_150–152-13">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBowker2000_14-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBowker2000-14">[8]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarvey2001xiii_15-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarvey2001xiii-15">[9]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Knott_sanatana_dharma_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-Knott_sanatana_dharma-16">[note 5]</a></sup> Another <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Endonym" title="Endonym">endonym</a> is <i>Vaidika dharma</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SmithBK1998_17-0"><a href="#cite_note-SmithBK1998-17">[10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharmaSharma20041–2_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharmaSharma20041–2-18">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier20142_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier20142-19">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007b7_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007b7-20">[13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sharma1985a_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sharma1985a-21">[14]</a></sup> the 'dharma related to the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a>.'<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-22"><a href="#cite_note-22">[15]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hinduism is a diverse system of thought marked by a range of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_philosophy" title="Hindu philosophy">philosophies</a> and shared concepts, <a href="/wiki/Ritual" title="Ritual">rituals</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_cosmology" title="Hindu cosmology">cosmological</a> systems, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_pilgrimage_sites" title="Hindu pilgrimage sites">pilgrimage sites</a>, and shared textual sources that discuss theology, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Metaphysic" title="Metaphysic">metaphysics</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_mythology" title="Hindu mythology">mythology</a>, Vedic <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">yajna</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">yoga</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">agamic</a> rituals, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">temple building</a>, among other topics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-23">[16]</a></sup> Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include the four <a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">Puruṣārthas</a>, the proper goals or aims of human life; namely, dharma (ethics/duties), <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">artha</a> (prosperity/work), <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">kama</a> (desires/passions) and <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">moksha</a> (liberation/freedom from the passions and the cycle of death and <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">rebirth</a>),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bilimoria_2007_p._103_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-Bilimoria_2007_p._103-24">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199711_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199711-25">[18]</a></sup> as well as <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a> (action, intent and consequences) and <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">saṃsāra</a> (cycle of death and rebirth).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier200746–52,_76–77_26-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier200746–52,_76–77-26">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003-27">[20]</a></sup> Hinduism prescribes the eternal duties, such as honesty, refraining from injuring living beings (<i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ahi%E1%B9%83s%C4%81" title="Ahiṃsā">Ahiṃsā</a></i>), patience, forbearance, self-restraint, virtue, and compassion, among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-28">[web 3]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-29"><a href="#cite_note-29">[21]</a></sup> Hindu practices include worship (<a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">puja</a>), fire rituals (<a href="/wiki/Homa_(ritual)" title="Homa (ritual)">homa/havan</a>), recitations (<a href="/wiki/Pravachan" title="Pravachan">pravachan</a>), devotion (<a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">bhakti</a>), chanting (<a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">japa</a>), meditation (<a href="/wiki/Dhyana_in_Hinduism" title="Dhyana in Hinduism">dhyāna</a>), sacrifice (<a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">yajña</a>), charity (<a href="/wiki/D%C4%81na" title="Dāna">dāna</a>), selfless service (<a href="/wiki/Sev%C4%81" title="Sevā">sevā</a>), homage to one's ancestors (<a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81ddha" title="Śrāddha">śrāddha</a>), family-oriented <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rites of passage</a>, annual <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hindu_festivals" title="List of Hindu festivals">festivals</a>, and occasional pilgrimages (<a href="/wiki/Yatra" title="Yatra">yatra</a>). Along with the practice of various yogas, some Hindus leave their social world and material possessions and engage in lifelong <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a> (monasticism) in order to achieve moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ellinger70_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-ellinger70-30">[22]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hindu texts are classified into <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Aruti" title="Śruti">Śruti</a> ("heard") and <a href="/wiki/Smriti" title="Smriti">Smṛti</a> ("remembered"), the major scriptures of which are the <i>Vedas</i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Purānas</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahābhārata</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Rāmāyana</a></i>, and the <i><a href="/wiki/Agama_(Hinduism)" title="Agama (Hinduism)">Āgamas</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier200746–52,_76–77_26-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier200746–52,_76–77-26">[19]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-31"><a href="#cite_note-31">[23]</a></sup> There are six <a href="/wiki/%C4%80stika_and_n%C4%81stika" title="Āstika and nāstika">āstika</a> schools of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_philosophy" title="Hindu philosophy">Hindu philosophy</a>, who recognise the authority of the Vedas, namely <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Sānkhya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)" title="Yoga (philosophy)">Yoga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyāya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vaisheshika" title="Vaisheshika">Vaisheshika</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C4%ABm%C4%81%E1%B9%83s%C4%81" title="Mīmāṃsā">Mimāmsā</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedānta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Matthew_Clarke_2011_28_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-Matthew_Clarke_2011_28-32">[24]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-33"><a href="#cite_note-33">[25]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[26]</a></sup> While the <a href="/wiki/Puranic_chronology" title="Puranic chronology">Puranic chronology</a> presents a genealogy of thousands of years, starting with the Vedic <i>rishis</i>, scholars regard Hinduism as a fusion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lockard-fusion_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-fusion-35">[note 6]</a></sup> or synthesis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008193_36-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008193-36">[27]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_37-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-37">[note 7]</a></sup> of <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion#Brahmanism" title="Historical Vedic religion">Brahmanical orthopraxy</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Brahmanism_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-Brahmanism-38">[note 8]</a></sup> with various Indian cultures,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-various_cultures_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-various_cultures-39">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fusion_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-40">[note 9]</a></sup> having diverse roots<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911-41">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roots_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-roots-42">[note 10]</a></sup> and no specific founder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler19971,_7_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler19971,_7-43">[30]</a></sup> This <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_synthesis" title="Hindu synthesis">Hindu synthesis</a> emerged after the Vedic period, between c. 500<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup>–200<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-45">[32]</a></sup> BCE and c. 300 CE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup> in the period of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Urbanisation" title="Second Urbanisation">Second Urbanisation</a> and the early <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hinduism#Hindu_synthesis_and_Classical_Hinduism_(c._200_BCE_–_1200_CE)" title="History of Hinduism">classical period of Hinduism</a>, when the <a href="/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry" title="Indian epic poetry">Epics</a> and the first Purānas were composed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_45-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-45">[32]</a></sup> It flourished in the <a href="/wiki/Medieval_India" title="Medieval India">medieval period</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent">decline of Buddhism in India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995109–111_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995109–111-46">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>Currently, the four major <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">denominations</a> of Hinduism are <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Smarta_tradition" title="Smarta tradition">Smarta tradition</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhandarkar1913_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhandarkar1913-47">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETattwanandan.d._48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETattwanandan.d.-48">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168-49">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner2009377,_398_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner2009377,_398-50">[37]</a></sup> Sources of authority and eternal truths in the Hindu texts play an important role, but there is also a strong Hindu tradition of questioning authority in order to deepen the understanding of these truths and to further develop the tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazierintrop2_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-frazierintrop2-51">[38]</a></sup> Hinduism is the most widely professed faith in <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_India" title="Religion in India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Nepal" title="Religion in Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Religion_in_Mauritius" title="Religion in Mauritius">Mauritius</a>. Significant numbers of Hindu communities are found in <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Southeast_Asia" title="Hinduism in Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> including in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bali" title="Hinduism in Bali">Bali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">Indonesia</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-52"><a href="#cite_note-52">[39]</a></sup> the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_West_Indies" title="Hinduism in the West Indies">Caribbean</a>, <a href="/wiki/North_America" title="North America">North America</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Europe" title="Hinduism in Europe">Europe</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Oceania" title="Hinduism in Oceania">Oceania</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Africa" title="Hinduism in Africa">Africa</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">other regions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-53"><a href="#cite_note-53">[40]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-54"><a href="#cite_note-54">[41]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r886046785">.mw-parser-output .toclimit-2 .toclevel-1 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-3 .toclevel-2 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-4 .toclevel-3 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-5 .toclevel-4 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-6 .toclevel-5 ul,.mw-parser-output .toclimit-7 .toclevel-6 ul{display:none}</style><div class="toclimit-3"><div aria-labelledby="mw-toc-heading" class="toc" id="toc" role="navigation"><input class="toctogglecheckbox" id="toctogglecheckbox" role="button" style="display:none" type="checkbox"/><div class="toctitle" dir="ltr" lang="en"><h2 id="mw-toc-heading">Contents</h2><span class="toctogglespan"><label class="toctogglelabel" for="toctogglecheckbox"></label></span></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Etymology">Etymology</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2809" data-file-width="4096" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg/220px-Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg/330px-Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg/440px-Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Salah_Satu_Upacara_Besar_Di_Pura_Agung_Besakih.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">puja</a> ceremony at <a href="/wiki/Besakih_Temple" title="Besakih Temple">Besakih Temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The word <i>Hindū</i> is derived from <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_languages" title="Indo-Aryan languages">Indo-Aryan</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood20083_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood20083-55">[42]</a></sup>/<a href="/wiki/Sanskrit" title="Sanskrit">Sanskrit</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup> root <i>Sindhu</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParpola2015"Chapter_1"_57-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParpola2015"Chapter_1"-57'>[44]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Proto-Iranian_language" title="Proto-Iranian language">Proto-Iranian</a> sound change <i>*s</i> &gt; <i>h</i> occurred between 850 and 600 BCE, according to <a href="/wiki/Asko_Parpola" title="Asko Parpola">Asko Parpola</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-58"><a href="#cite_note-58">[45]</a></sup>
</p><p>The use of the English term "Hinduism" to describe a collection of practices and beliefs is a fairly recent construction: it was first used by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_Ram_Mohun_Roy" title="Raja Ram Mohun Roy">Raja Ram Mohan Roy</a> in 1816–17.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2008433_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2008433-59">[46]</a></sup> The term "Hinduism" was coined in around 1830, and appropriated by those Indians who opposed British colonialism, and who wanted to distinguish themselves from Muslims and Christians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier201017_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier201017-60">[47]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger20145_61-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger20145-61">[48]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEParpola20155_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParpola20155-62">[49]</a></sup> Before the British began to categorise communities strictly by religion, Indians generally did not define themselves exclusively through their religious beliefs; instead identities were largely segmented on the basis of locality, language, <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varṇa</a>, <a href="/wiki/J%C4%81ti" title="Jāti">jāti</a>, occupation, and sect.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger20143_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger20143-63">[50]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-66"><a href="#cite_note-66">[note 11]</a></sup> In the 18th century, the European merchants and colonists began to refer to the followers of <a href="/wiki/Indian_religions" title="Indian religions">Indian religions</a> collectively as Hindus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-amp.scroll.in_64-1"><a href="#cite_note-amp.scroll.in-64">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>The word "Hindu" is much older, and it is believed that it was used as the name for the <a href="/wiki/Indus_River" title="Indus River">Indus River</a> in the northwestern part of the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2008433_59-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2008433-59">[46]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-67"><a href="#cite_note-67">[note 12]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Gavin_Flood" title="Gavin Flood">Gavin Flood</a>, "The actual term <i>Hindu</i> first occurs as a <a href="/wiki/Persian_language" title="Persian language">Persian</a> geographical term for the people who lived beyond the river Indus (Sanskrit: <i>Sindhu</i>)",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup> more specifically in the 6th-century BCE inscription of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Darius_I" title="Darius I">Darius I</a> (550–486 BCE).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2002_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2002-68">[53]</a></sup> The term <i>Hindu</i> in these ancient records is a geographical term and did not refer to a religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup> Among the earliest known records of 'Hindu' with connotations of religion may be in the 7th-century CE Chinese text <i>Record of the Western Regions</i> by <a href="/wiki/Xuanzang" title="Xuanzang">Xuanzang</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2002_68-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2002-68">[53]</a></sup> and 14th-century Persian text <i>Futuhu's-salatin</i> by 'Abd al-Malik <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Isami_(historian)" title="Isami (historian)">Isami</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_term_10-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_term-10">[note 3]</a></sup>
</p><p>Thapar states that the word <i>Hindu</i> is found as <i>heptahindu</i> in <a href="/wiki/Avesta" title="Avesta">Avesta</a> – equivalent to Rigvedic <i>sapta sindhu</i>, while <i>hndstn</i> (pronounced <i>Hindustan</i>) is found in a <a href="/wiki/Sasanian_Empire" title="Sasanian Empire">Sasanian</a> inscription from the 3rd century CE, both of which refer to parts of northwestern South Asia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-69"><a href="#cite_note-69">[54]</a></sup> The Arabic term <i>al-Hind</i> referred to the people who live across the River Indus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThapar199377_70-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThapar199377-70">[55]</a></sup> This Arabic term was itself taken from the pre-Islamic Persian term <i>Hindū</i>, which refers to all Indians. By the 13th century, <i><a href="/wiki/Hindustan" title="Hindustan">Hindustan</a></i> emerged as a popular alternative <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Names_of_India" title="Names of India">name of India</a>, meaning the "land of Hindus".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEThompson_Platts1884_71-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEThompson_Platts1884-71">[56]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-73"><a href="#cite_note-73">[note 13]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term <i>Hindu</i> was later used occasionally in some Sanskrit texts such as the later <i><a href="/wiki/Rajatarangini" title="Rajatarangini">Rajataranginis</a></i> of Kashmir (Hinduka, c. 1450) and some 16th- to 18th-century <a href="/wiki/Bengali_language" title="Bengali language">Bengali</a> <a href="/wiki/Gaudiya_Vaishnavism" title="Gaudiya Vaishnavism">Gaudiya Vaishnava</a> texts including <i><a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Charitamrita" title="Chaitanya Charitamrita">Chaitanya Charitamrita</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Chaitanya_Bhagavata" title="Chaitanya Bhagavata">Chaitanya Bhagavata</a></i>. These texts used it to distinguish Hindus from Muslims who are called <a href="/wiki/Yona#Later_meanings" title="Yona">Yavanas</a> (foreigners) or <a href="/wiki/Mleccha" title="Mleccha">Mlecchas</a> (barbarians), with the 16th-century <i>Chaitanya Charitamrita</i> text and the 17th-century <i>Bhakta Mala</i> text using the phrase "<i>Hindu dharma</i>".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-74"><a href="#cite_note-74">[58]</a></sup> It was only towards the end of the 18th century that European merchants and colonists began to refer to the followers of Indian religions collectively as <i>Hindus</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[note 14]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term <i>Hinduism</i>, then spelled <i>Hindooism</i>, was introduced into the English language in the 18th century to denote the religious, philosophical, and cultural traditions native to India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweetman2003_79-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sweetman2003-79">[62]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Definitions">Definitions</span></h2>
<p>Hinduism includes a diversity of ideas on <a href="/wiki/Spirituality#Hinduism" title="Spirituality">spirituality</a> and traditions, but has no ecclesiastical order, no unquestionable religious authorities, no governing body, no prophet(s) nor any binding holy book; Hindus can choose to be <a href="/wiki/Polytheism" title="Polytheism">polytheistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pantheism" title="Pantheism">pantheistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Panentheism" title="Panentheism">panentheistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Pandeism" title="Pandeism">pandeistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henotheism" title="Henotheism">henotheistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monotheism" title="Monotheism">monotheistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Monism" title="Monism">monistic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Agnosticism" title="Agnosticism">agnostic</a>, <a href="/wiki/Atheism" title="Atheism">atheistic</a> or <a href="/wiki/Humanism" title="Humanism">humanist</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lipner2009p8_80-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lipner2009p8-80">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-81"><a href="#cite_note-81">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-82"><a href="#cite_note-82">[65]</a></sup> According to Doniger, "ideas about all the major issues of faith and lifestyle – vegetarianism, nonviolence, belief in rebirth, even <a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">caste</a> – are subjects of debate, not <a href="/wiki/Dogma" title="Dogma">dogma</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger20143_63-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger20143-63">[50]</a></sup>
</p><p>Because of the wide range of traditions and ideas covered by the term Hinduism, arriving at a comprehensive definition is difficult.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup> The religion "defies our desire to define and categorize it".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnott1998117_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnott1998117-83">[66]</a></sup> Hinduism has been variously defined as a religion, a religious tradition, a set of religious beliefs, and "a way of life".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200312–13_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200312–13-84">[67]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-definition_2-1"><a href="#cite_note-definition-2">[note 1]</a></sup> From a Western lexical standpoint, Hinduism like other faiths is appropriately referred to as a religion. In India, the term <i>dharma</i> is preferred, which is broader than the Western term <i>religion</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-85"><a href="#cite_note-85">[68]</a></sup>
</p><p>The study of India and its cultures and religions, and the definition of "Hinduism", has been shaped by the interests of colonialism and by Western notions of religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman2004_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman2004-86">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-87">[70]</a></sup> Since the 1990s, those influences and its outcomes have been the topic of debate among scholars of Hinduism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman2004_86-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman2004-86">[69]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-88"><a href="#cite_note-88">[note 15]</a></sup> and have also been taken over by critics of the Western view on India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENussbaum2009_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENussbaum2009-89">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-90"><a href="#cite_note-90">[note 16]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Typology">Typology</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="507" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/220px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/330px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg/440px-Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Aum_Om_navy_blue_circle_coral.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">Om</a>, a stylized letter of <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a> script, used as a religious symbol in Hinduism</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<p>Hinduism as it is commonly known can be subdivided into a number of major currents. Of the historical division into six <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Darsanas" title="Darsanas">darsanas</a> (philosophies), two schools, <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedanta</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)" title="Yoga (philosophy)">Yoga</a>, are currently the most prominent.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Matthew_Clarke_2011_28_32-1"><a href="#cite_note-Matthew_Clarke_2011_28-32">[24]</a></sup> Classified by primary deity or deities, four major Hinduism modern currents are <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> (Shiva), <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> (Vishnu), <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> (Devi) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smarta_Tradition" title="Smarta Tradition">Smartism</a> (five deities treated as equals).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhandarkar1913_47-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhandarkar1913-47">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETattwanandan.d._48-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETattwanandan.d.-48">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168_49-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168-49">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner2009377,_398_50-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner2009377,_398-50">[37]</a></sup> Hinduism also accepts numerous divine beings, with many Hindus considering the deities to be aspects or manifestations of a single impersonal absolute or ultimate reality or God, while some Hindus maintain that a specific deity represents the supreme and various deities are lower manifestations of this supreme.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199614_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199614-91">[72]</a></sup> Other notable characteristics include a belief in the existence of <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">ātman</a> (Self), <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">reincarnation</a> of one's ātman, and karma as well as a belief in dharma (duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues and right way of living), although variation exists, with some not following these beliefs.
</p><p>McDaniel (2007) classifies Hinduism into six major kinds and numerous minor kinds, in order to understand the expression of emotions among the Hindus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-junemcdaniel6_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-junemcdaniel6-92">[73]</a></sup> The major kinds, according to McDaniel are <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Folk_Hinduism" title="Folk Hinduism">Folk Hinduism</a>, based on local traditions and cults of local <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deities" title="Deities">deities</a> and is the oldest, non-literate system; <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Vedic Hinduism</a> based on the earliest layers of the Vedas traceable to 2nd millennium BCE; Vedantic Hinduism based on the philosophy of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Upanishad" title="Upanishad">Upanishads</a>, including <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>, emphasizing knowledge and wisdom; Yogic Hinduism, following the text of <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Yoga Sutras of Patanjali</a> emphasizing introspective awareness; Dharmic Hinduism or "daily morality", which McDaniel states is stereotyped in some books as the "only form of Hindu religion with a belief in karma, cows and caste"; and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">bhakti</a> or devotional Hinduism, where intense emotions are elaborately incorporated in the pursuit of the spiritual.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-junemcdaniel6_92-1"><a href="#cite_note-junemcdaniel6-92">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>Michaels distinguishes three Hindu religions and four forms of Hindu religiosity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421-93">[74]</a></sup> The three Hindu religions are "Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism", "folk religions and tribal religions", and "founded religions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422_94-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422-94">[75]</a></sup> The four forms of Hindu religiosity are the classical "karma-marga",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423-95">[76]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jnana_yoga" title="Jnana yoga">jnana-marga</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-96">[77]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_yoga" title="Bhakti yoga">bhakti-marga</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-96">[77]</a></sup> and "heroism", which is rooted in <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa#Warrior_ascetics" title="Sannyasa">militaristic traditions</a>. These militaristic traditions include Ramaism (the worship of a hero of epic literature, <a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">Rama</a>, believing him to be an incarnation of Vishnu)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-97"><a href="#cite_note-97">[78]</a></sup> and parts of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_nationalism" title="Hindu nationalism">political Hinduism</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423_95-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200423-95">[76]</a></sup>  "Heroism" is also called <a href="/wiki/V%C4%ABrya_(Hinduism)" title="Vīrya (Hinduism)">virya-marga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424_96-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200424-96">[77]</a></sup> According to Michaels, one out of nine Hindu belongs by birth to one or both of the Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism and Folk religion typology, whether practicing or non-practicing. He classifies most Hindus as belonging by choice to one of the "founded religions" such as Vaishnavism and Shaivism that are moksha-focussed and often de-emphasize Brahman priestly authority yet incorporate ritual grammar of Brahmanic-Sanskritic Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421–22_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200421–22-98">[79]</a></sup> He includes among "founded religions" <a href="/wiki/Buddhism" title="Buddhism">Buddhism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Jainism" title="Jainism">Jainism</a>, Sikhism that are now distinct religions, <a href="/wiki/Syncretism" title="Syncretism">syncretic</a> movements such as <a href="/wiki/Brahmo_Samaj" title="Brahmo Samaj">Brahmo Samaj</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Theosophical_Society" title="Theosophical Society">Theosophical Society</a>, as well as various "<a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">Guru</a>-isms" and new religious movements such as <a href="/wiki/Maharishi_Mahesh_Yogi" title="Maharishi Mahesh Yogi">Maharishi Mahesh Yogi</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISKCON" title="ISKCON">ISKCON</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422–23_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200422–23-99">[80]</a></sup>
</p><p>Inden states that the attempt to classify Hinduism by typology started in the imperial times, when proselytizing missionaries and colonial officials sought to understand and portray Hinduism from their interests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-100">[81]</a></sup> Hinduism was construed as emanating not from a reason of spirit but fantasy and creative imagination, not conceptual but symbolical, not ethical but emotive, not rational or spiritual but of cognitive mysticism. This stereotype followed and fit, states Inden, with the imperial imperatives of the era, providing the moral justification for the colonial project.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_100-1"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-100">[81]</a></sup> From tribal Animism to Buddhism, everything was subsumed as part of Hinduism. The early reports set the tradition and scholarly premises for the typology of Hinduism, as well as the major assumptions and flawed presuppositions that have been at the foundation of <a href="/wiki/Indology" title="Indology">Indology</a>. Hinduism, according to Inden, has been neither what imperial religionists stereotyped it to be, nor is it appropriate to equate Hinduism to be merely the monist pantheism and philosophical idealism of Advaita Vedanta.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_100-2"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-100">[81]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_views">Hindu views</span></h3>
<h4><span id="San.C4.81tana_Dharma"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Sanātana_Dharma"><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">Sanātana Dharma</i></span></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tan%C4%AB" title="Sanātanī">Sanātanī</a></div>
<p>To its adherents, Hinduism is a traditional way of life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-101"><a href="#cite_note-101">[82]</a></sup> Many practitioners refer to the "orthodox" form of Hinduism as <i><a href="/wiki/San%C4%81tana_Dharma" title="Sanātana Dharma"><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">Sanātana Dharma</i></span></a></i>, "the eternal law" or the "eternal way".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-102"><a href="#cite_note-102">[83]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVivekjivandas20101_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVivekjivandas20101-103">[84]</a></sup> Hindus regard Hinduism to be thousands of years old. The <a href="/wiki/Puranic_chronology" title="Puranic chronology">Puranic chronology</a>, the timeline of events in ancient Indian history as narrated in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahabaratha" title="Mahabaratha">Mahabaratha</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Ramayana" title="Ramayana">Ramayana</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>, envisions a chronology of events related to Hinduism starting well before 3000 BCE. The Sanskrit word <i>dharma</i> has a much broader meaning than <i><a href="/wiki/Religion" title="Religion">religion</a></i> and is not its equivalent. All aspects of a Hindu life, namely acquiring wealth (artha), fulfillment of desires (kama), and attaining liberation (moksha), are part of dharma, which encapsulates the "right way of living" and eternal harmonious principles in their fulfillment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnott1998111_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnott1998111-104">[85]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-105"><a href="#cite_note-105">[86]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the editors of the Encyclopædia Britannica, <i><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">Sanātana Dharma</i></span></i> historically referred to the "eternal" duties religiously ordained in Hinduism, duties such as honesty, refraining from injuring living beings (<i><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahiṃsā</a></i>), purity, goodwill, mercy, patience, forbearance, self-restraint, generosity, and asceticism. These duties applied regardless of a Hindu's class, caste, or sect, and they contrasted with <a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita#Svadharma_and_svabhava" title="Bhagavad Gita">svadharma</a>, one's "own duty", in accordance with one's class or caste (varṇa) and stage in life (<a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">puruṣārtha</a>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_28-1"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-28">[web 3]</a></sup> In recent years, the term has been used by Hindu leaders, reformers, and nationalists to refer to Hinduism. Sanatana dharma has become a synonym for the "eternal" truth and teachings of Hinduism, that transcend history and are "unchanging, indivisible and ultimately nonsectarian".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-EB-sanatana_dharma_28-2"><a href="#cite_note-EB-sanatana_dharma-28">[web 3]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to other scholars such as Kim Knott and Brian Hatcher, Sanātana Dharma refers to "timeless, eternal set of truths" and this is how Hindus view the origins of their religion. It is viewed as those eternal truths and tradition with origins beyond human history, truths divinely revealed (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shruti" title="Shruti">Shruti</a>) in the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedas</a> – the most ancient of the world's scriptures.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHatcher20154–5,_69–71,_150–152_13-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHatcher20154–5,_69–71,_150–152-13">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKnott19983_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKnott19983-106">[87]</a></sup> To many Hindus, the Western term "religion" to the extent it means "dogma and an institution traceable to a single founder" is inappropriate for their tradition, states Hatcher. Hinduism, to them, is a tradition that can be traced at least to the ancient Vedic era.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHatcher20154–5,_69–71,_150–152_13-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHatcher20154–5,_69–71,_150–152-13">[7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17-107">[88]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-109"><a href="#cite_note-109">[note 17]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Vaidika_dharma"><i>Vaidika dharma</i></span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">Historical Vedic religion</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a></div>
<p>Some have referred to Hinduism as the <i>Vaidika dharma</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharmaSharma20041–2_18-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharmaSharma20041–2-18">[11]</a></sup> The word 'Vaidika' in Sanskrit means 'derived from or conformable to the Veda' or 'relating to the Veda'.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-MW_Vaidika_dharma_110-0"><a href="#cite_note-MW_Vaidika_dharma-110">[web 4]</a></sup> Traditional scholars employed the terms Vaidika and Avaidika, those who accept the Vedas as a source of authoritative knowledge and those who do not, to differentiate various Indian schools from Jainism, Buddhism and Charvaka. According to Klaus Klostermaier, the term Vaidika dharma is the earliest self-designation of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier20142_19-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier20142-19">[12]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007b7_20-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007b7-20">[13]</a></sup> According to <a href="/wiki/Arvind_Sharma" title="Arvind Sharma">Arvind Sharma</a>, the historical evidence suggests that "the Hindus were referring to their religion by the term <i>vaidika dharma</i> or a variant thereof" by the 4th-century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sharma1985a_21-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sharma1985a-21">[14]</a></sup> According to Brian K. Smith, "[i]t is 'debatable at the very least' as to whether the term <i>Vaidika Dharma</i> cannot, with the proper concessions to historical, cultural, and ideological specificity, be comparable to and translated as 'Hinduism' or 'Hindu religion'."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-SmithBK1998_17-1"><a href="#cite_note-SmithBK1998-17">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Whatever the case, many Hindu religious sources see persons or groups which they consider as non-Vedic (and which reject Vedic <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Varnasrama_Dharma" title="Varnasrama Dharma">varṇāśrama</a> - 'caste and life stage' orthodoxy) as being heretics (pāṣaṇḍa/pākhaṇḍa). For example, the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavata_Purana" title="Bhagavata Purana">Bhāgavata Purāṇa</a>,</i> an extremely influential Hindu Puranic source, considers Buddhists, Jains as well as some <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaiva</a> groups like the <a href="/wiki/Pashupata_Shaivism" title="Pashupata Shaivism">Paśupatas</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kapalika" title="Kapalika">Kāpālins</a> to be pāṣaṇḍas (heretics).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-111"><a href="#cite_note-111">[90]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Sanderson" title="Alexis Sanderson">Alexis Sanderson</a>, the early Sanskrit texts differentiate between Vaidika, Vaishnava, Shaiva, Shakta, Saura, Buddhist and Jaina traditions. However, the late 1st-millennium CE Indic consensus had "indeed come to conceptualize a complex entity corresponding to Hinduism as opposed to Buddhism and Jainism excluding only certain forms of <a href="/wiki/Antinomianism" title="Antinomianism">antinomian</a> Shakta-Shaiva" from its fold.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandersonpart1_112-0"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart1-112">[web 5]</a></sup> Some in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mimamsa" title="Mimamsa">Mimamsa</a> school of Hindu philosophy considered the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/%C4%80gama_(Hinduism)" title="Āgama (Hinduism)">Agamas</a></i> such as the Pancaratrika to be invalid because it did not conform to the Vedas. Some Kashmiri scholars rejected the esoteric tantric traditions to be a part of Vaidika dharma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandersonpart1_112-1"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart1-112">[web 5]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-113"><a href="#cite_note-113">[web 6]</a></sup> The Atimarga Shaivism ascetic tradition, datable to about 500 CE, challenged the Vaidika frame and insisted that their Agamas and practices were not only valid, they were superior than those of the Vaidikas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandersonpart3_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart3-114">[web 7]</a></sup> However, adds Sanderson, this Shaiva ascetic tradition viewed themselves as being genuinely true to the Vedic tradition and "held unanimously that the Śruti and Smṛti of Brahmanism are universally and uniquely valid in their own sphere, [...] and that as such they [Vedas] are man's sole means of valid knowledge [...]".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandersonpart3_114-1"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart3-114">[web 7]</a></sup>
</p><p>The term Vaidika dharma means a code of practice that is "based on the Vedas", but it is unclear what "based on the Vedas" really implies, states Julius Lipner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17_107-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17-107">[88]</a></sup> The Vaidika dharma or "Vedic way of life", states Lipner, does not mean "Hinduism is necessarily religious" or that Hindus have a universally accepted "conventional or institutional meaning" for that term.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17_107-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17-107">[88]</a></sup> To many, it is as much a cultural term. Many Hindus do not have a copy of the Vedas nor have they ever seen or personally read parts of a Veda, like a Christian, might relate to the Bible or a Muslim might to the Quran. Yet, states Lipner, "this does not mean that their [Hindus] whole life's orientation cannot be traced to the Vedas or that it does not in some way derive from it".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17_107-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17-107">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>Though many religious Hindus implicitly acknowledge the authority of the Vedas, this acknowledgment is often "no more than a declaration that someone considers himself [or herself] a Hindu,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner200916_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner200916-115">[91]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[note 18]</a></sup> and "most Indians today pay lip service to the Veda and have no regard for the contents of the text."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-117"><a href="#cite_note-117">[92]</a></sup> Some Hindus challenge the authority of the Vedas, thereby implicitly acknowledging its importance to the history of Hinduism, states Lipner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17_107-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner200915–17-107">[88]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Hindu_modernism">Hindu modernism</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_reform_movements" title="Hindu reform movements">Hindu reform movements</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1280" data-file-width="933" decoding="async" height="302" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/220px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/330px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0b/Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg/440px-Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Swami_Vivekananda-1893-09-signed.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda" title="Swami Vivekananda">Swami Vivekananda</a> was a key figure in introducing <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedanta</a> and Yoga in Europe and the United States,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFeuerstein2002600_118-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFeuerstein2002600-118">[93]</a></sup> raising interfaith awareness and making Hinduism a world religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEClarke2006209_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEClarke2006209-119">[94]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Beginning in the 19th century, Indian modernists re-asserted Hinduism as a major asset of Indian civilisation,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-87">[70]</a></sup> meanwhile "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233-120">[95]</a></sup> and elevating the Vedic elements. Western stereotypes were reversed, emphasizing the universal aspects, and introducing modern approaches of social problems.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_87-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-87">[70]</a></sup> This approach had a great appeal, not only in India, but also in the west.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999_87-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999-87">[70]</a></sup> Major representatives of <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">"Hindu modernism"</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_121-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-121">[96]</a></sup> are <a href="/wiki/Ram_Mohan_Roy" title="Ram Mohan Roy">Ram Mohan Roy</a>, <a href="/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda" title="Swami Vivekananda">Swami Vivekananda</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sarvepalli_Radhakrishnan" title="Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan">Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mahatma_Gandhi" title="Mahatma Gandhi">Mahatma Gandhi</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996256–261_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996256–261-122">[97]</a></sup>
Raja Rammohan Roy is known as the father of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_Renaissance" title="Hindu Renaissance">Hindu Renaissance</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-hindu1_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-hindu1-123">[98]</a></sup> He was a major influence on Swami Vivekananda (1863–1902), who, according to Flood, was "a figure of great importance in the development of a modern Hindu self-understanding and in formulating the West's view of Hinduism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996257_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996257-124">[99]</a></sup> Central to his philosophy is the idea that the divine exists in all beings, that all human beings can achieve union with this "innate divinity",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_121-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-121">[96]</a></sup> and that seeing this divine as the essence of others will further love and social harmony.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_121-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-121">[96]</a></sup> According to Vivekananda, there is an essential unity to Hinduism, which underlies the diversity of its many forms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258_121-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996258-121">[96]</a></sup> According to Flood, Vivekananda's vision of Hinduism "is one generally accepted by most English-speaking middle-class Hindus today".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996259_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996259-125">[100]</a></sup> Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan sought to reconcile western rationalism with Hinduism, "presenting Hinduism as an essentially rationalistic and humanistic religious experience".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996249_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996249-126">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>This "Global Hinduism"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-127">[102]</a></sup> has a worldwide appeal, transcending national boundaries<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_127-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-127">[102]</a></sup> and, according to Flood, "becoming a world religion alongside Christianity, Islam and Buddhism",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_127-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-127">[102]</a></sup> both for the Hindu diaspora communities and for westerners who are attracted to non-western cultures and religions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_127-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-127">[102]</a></sup> It emphasizes universal spiritual values such as social justice, peace and "the spiritual transformation of humanity".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265_127-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996265-127">[102]</a></sup> It has developed partly due to "re-enculturation",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-128">[103]</a></sup> or the <a href="/wiki/Pizza_effect" title="Pizza effect">Pizza effect</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_128-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-128">[103]</a></sup> in which elements of Hindu culture have been exported to the West, gaining popularity there, and as a consequence also gained greater popularity in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267_128-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267-128">[103]</a></sup> This globalization of Hindu culture brought "to the West teachings which have become an important cultural force in western societies, and which in turn have become an important cultural force in India, their place of origin".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267–268_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996267–268-129">[104]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Legal_definitions">Legal definitions</span></h4>
<p>The definition of Hinduism in Indian Law is: "Acceptance of the Vedas with reverence; recognition of the fact that the means or ways to <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a> are diverse; and realization of the truth that the number of gods to be worshipped is large".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-130"><a href="#cite_note-130">[105]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger201420_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger201420-131">[106]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Scholarly_views">Scholarly views</span></h3>
<p>The term <i>Hinduism</i> was coined in Western ethnography in the 18th century,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweetman2003_79-1"><a href="#cite_note-Sweetman2003-79">[62]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[note 19]</a></sup> and refers to the fusion<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lockard-fusion_35-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lockard-fusion-35">[note 6]</a></sup> or synthesis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hiltebeitel-synthesis_37-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hiltebeitel-synthesis-37">[note 7]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESamuel2008193_36-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESamuel2008193-36">[27]</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-various_cultures_39-1"><a href="#cite_note-various_cultures-39">[28]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-fusion_40-1"><a href="#cite_note-fusion-40">[note 9]</a></sup> with diverse roots<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911_41-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911-41">[29]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-roots_42-1"><a href="#cite_note-roots-42">[note 10]</a></sup> and no founder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler19971,_7_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler19971,_7-43">[30]</a></sup> This <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_synthesis" title="Hindu synthesis">Hindu synthesis</a> emerged after the Vedic period, between c. 500<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup>–200<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_45-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-45">[32]</a></sup> BCE and c. 300 CE,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-4"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup> in the period of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Second_Urbanisation" title="Second Urbanisation">Second Urbanisation</a> and the early classical period of Hinduism, when the <a href="/wiki/Indian_epic_poetry" title="Indian epic poetry">Epics</a> and the first Puranas were composed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-5"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson2009_45-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson2009-45">[32]</a></sup> It flourished in the <a href="/wiki/Medieval_India" title="Medieval India">medieval period</a>, with the <a href="/wiki/Decline_of_Buddhism_in_the_Indian_subcontinent" title="Decline of Buddhism in the Indian subcontinent">decline of Buddhism in India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELarson1995109–111_46-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELarson1995109–111-46">[33]</a></sup> Hinduism's tolerance to variations in belief and its broad range of traditions make it difficult to define as a religion according to traditional Western conceptions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETurner1996a275_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETurner1996a275-134">[107]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some academics suggest that Hinduism can be seen as a category with "fuzzy edges" rather than as a well-defined and rigid entity. Some forms of religious expression are central to Hinduism and others, while not as central, still remain within the category. Based on this idea <a href="/wiki/Gabriella_Eichinger_Ferro-Luzzi" title="Gabriella Eichinger Ferro-Luzzi">Gabriella Eichinger Ferro-Luzzi</a> has developed a 'Prototype Theory approach' to the definition of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-135"><a href="#cite_note-135">[108]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Diversity_and_unity">Diversity and unity</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Diversity">Diversity</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ganapati.1..JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="4608" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ganapati.1..JPG/220px-Ganapati.1..JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ganapati.1..JPG/330px-Ganapati.1..JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/eb/Ganapati.1..JPG/440px-Ganapati.1..JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ganapati.1..JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> is one of the best-known and most worshipped deities in the <a href="/wiki/Hindu_deities" title="Hindu deities">Hindu pantheon</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Hindu beliefs are vast and diverse, and thus Hinduism is often referred to as a family of religions rather than a single religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-136"><a href="#cite_note-136">[web 9]</a></sup> Within each religion in this family of religions, there are different theologies, practices, and sacred texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[web 10]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-138"><a href="#cite_note-138">[109]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-139"><a href="#cite_note-139">[110]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-140"><a href="#cite_note-140">[111]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-141"><a href="#cite_note-141">[web 11]</a></sup> Hinduism does not have a "unified system of belief encoded in a declaration of faith or a <a href="/wiki/Creed" title="Creed">creed</a>",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19966_56-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19966-56">[43]</a></sup> but is rather an umbrella term comprising the plurality of religious phenomena of India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-142"><a href="#cite_note-142">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911–22_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911–22-143">[113]</a></sup> According to the Supreme Court of India,
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Unlike other religions in the World, the Hindu religion does not claim any one Prophet, it does not worship any one God, it does not believe in any one philosophic concept, it does not follow any one act of religious rites or performances; in fact, it does not satisfy the traditional features of a religion or creed. It is a way of life and nothing more".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier19941_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier19941-144">[114]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>Part of the problem with a single definition of the term <i>Hinduism</i> is the fact that Hinduism does not have a founder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood19961,_7_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood19961,_7-145">[115]</a></sup> It is a synthesis of various traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-146"><a href="#cite_note-146">[116]</a></sup> the "Brahmanical orthopraxy, the renouncer traditions and popular or local traditions".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-147">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Theism" title="Theism">Theism</a> is also difficult to use as a unifying doctrine for Hinduism, because while some Hindu philosophies postulate a theistic <a href="/wiki/Ontology" title="Ontology">ontology</a> of creation, other <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atheism_in_Hinduism" title="Atheism in Hinduism">Hindus are or have been atheists</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-148"><a href="#cite_note-148">[118]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Sense_of_unity">Sense of unity</span></h3>
<p>Despite the differences, there is also a sense of unity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-149">[119]</a></sup> Most Hindu traditions revere a body of religious or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sastra" title="Sastra">sacred literature</a>, the Vedas,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-150">[120]</a></sup> although there are exceptions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199635_151-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199635-151">[121]</a></sup> These texts are a reminder of the ancient cultural heritage and point of pride for Hindus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-andreapinkney_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-andreapinkney-152">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-153"><a href="#cite_note-153">[123]</a></sup> though <a href="/wiki/Louis_Renou" title="Louis Renou">Louis Renou</a> stated that "even in the most orthodox domains, the reverence to the Vedas has come to be a simple raising of the hat".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-andreapinkney_152-1"><a href="#cite_note-andreapinkney-152">[122]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911_154-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass19911-154">[124]</a></sup>
</p><p>Halbfass states that, although Shaivism and Vaishnavism may be regarded as "self-contained religious constellations",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_149-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-149">[119]</a></sup> there is a degree of interaction and reference between the "theoreticians and literary representatives"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_149-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-149">[119]</a></sup> of each tradition that indicates the presence of "a wider sense of identity, a sense of coherence in a shared context and of inclusion in a common framework and horizon".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115_149-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass199115-149">[119]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Classical_Hinduism">Classical Hinduism</span></h4>
<p><a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmins</a> played an essential role in the development of the post-Vedic Hindu synthesis, disseminating Vedic culture to local communities, and integrating local religiosity into the trans-regional Brahmanic culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutschDalvi200499–100_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutschDalvi200499–100-155">[125]</a></sup> In the post-<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Gupta_empire" title="Gupta empire">Gupta period</a> Vedanta developed in southern India, where <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmanism" title="Brahmanism">orthodox Brahmanic culture</a> and the Hindu culture were preserved,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutschDalvi2004100–101_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutschDalvi2004100–101-156">[126]</a></sup> building on ancient Vedic traditions while "accommoda[ting] the multiple demands of Hinduism."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutschDalvi2004101_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutschDalvi2004101-157">[127]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Medieval_developments">Medieval developments</span></h4>
<p>The notion of common denominators for several religions and traditions of India further developed from the 12th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-158"><a href="#cite_note-158">[128]</a></sup> Lorenzen traces the emergence of a "family resemblance", and what he calls as "beginnings of medieval and modern Hinduism" taking shape, at c. 300–600 CE, with the development of the early Puranas, and continuities with the earlier Vedic religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200636-159">[129]</a></sup> Lorenzen states that the establishment of a Hindu self-identity took place "through a process of mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim Other".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648-160">[130]</a></sup> According to Lorenzen, this "presence of the Other"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648_160-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648-160">[130]</a></sup> is necessary to recognise the "loose family resemblance" among the various traditions and schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648,_655_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999648,_655-161">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to the Indologist <a href="/wiki/Alexis_Sanderson" title="Alexis Sanderson">Alexis Sanderson</a>, before Islam arrived in India, the "Sanskrit sources differentiated Vaidika, Vaiṣṇava, Śaiva, Śākta, Saura, Buddhist, and Jaina traditions, but they had no name that denotes the first five of these as a collective entity over and against Buddhism and Jainism". This absence of a formal name, states Sanderson, does not mean that the corresponding concept of Hinduism did not exist. By late 1st-millennium CE, the concept of a belief and tradition distinct from Buddhism and Jainism had emerged.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandersonpart1_112-2"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart1-112">[web 5]</a></sup> This complex tradition accepted in its identity almost all of what is currently Hinduism, except certain <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antinomian" title="Antinomian">antinomian</a> tantric movements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandersonpart1_112-3"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart1-112">[web 5]</a></sup> Some conservative thinkers of those times questioned whether certain Shaiva, Vaishnava and Shakta texts or practices were consistent with the Vedas, or were invalid in their entirety. Moderates then, and most orthoprax scholars later, agreed that though there are some variations, the foundation of their beliefs, the ritual grammar, the spiritual premises, and the soteriologies were the same. "This sense of greater unity", states Sanderson, "came to be called Hinduism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandersonpart1_112-4"><a href="#cite_note-sandersonpart1-112">[web 5]</a></sup>
