</p><p>According to Nicholson, already between the 12th and the 16th centuries "certain thinkers began to treat as a single whole the diverse philosophical teachings of the Upanishads, epics, Puranas, and the schools known retrospectively as the 'six systems' (<i>saddarsana</i>) of mainstream Hindu philosophy."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson20102_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson20102-162">[132]</a></sup> The tendency of "a blurring of philosophical distinctions" has also been noted by <a href="/wiki/Mikel_Burley" title="Mikel Burley">Mikel Burley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBurley200734_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBurley200734-163">[133]</a></sup> Hacker called this "inclusivism"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_150-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-150">[120]</a></sup> and Michaels speaks of "the identificatory habit".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_23-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-23">[16]</a></sup> Lorenzen locates the origins of a distinct Hindu identity in the interaction between Muslims and Hindus,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200624–33_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200624–33-164">[134]</a></sup> and a process of "mutual self-definition with a contrasting Muslim other",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200627_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200627-165">[135]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2002_68-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2002-68">[53]</a></sup> which started well before 1800.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200626–27_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200626–27-166">[136]</a></sup> Michaels notes:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>As a counteraction to Islamic supremacy and as part of the continuing process of regionalization, two religious innovations developed in the Hindu religions: the formation of sects and a historicization which preceded later nationalism ... [S]aints and sometimes militant sect leaders, such as the Marathi poet Tukaram (1609–1649) and Ramdas (1608–1681), articulated ideas in which they glorified Hinduism and the past. The Brahmins also produced increasingly historical texts, especially eulogies and chronicles of sacred sites (Mahatmyas), or developed a reflexive passion for collecting and compiling extensive collections of quotations on various subjects.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200444-167">[137]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_period_and_neo-Vedanta">Colonial period and neo-Vedanta</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Orientalism" title="Orientalism">Orientalism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Neo-Vedanta" title="Neo-Vedanta">Neo-Vedanta</a></div>
<p>This inclusivism<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-168"><a href="#cite_note-168">[138]</a></sup> was further developed in the 19th and 20th centuries by <a href="/wiki/Hindu_reform_movements" title="Hindu reform movements">Hindu reform movements</a> and Neo-Vedanta,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing2001_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing2001-169">[139]</a></sup> and has become characteristic of modern Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENicholson2010_150-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENicholson2010-150">[120]</a></sup>
</p><p>The notion and reports on "Hinduism" as a "single world religious tradition"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102-170">[140]</a></sup> was also popularised by 19th-century proselytizing missionaries and European Indologists, roles sometimes served by the same person, who relied on texts preserved by Brahmins (priests) for their information of Indian religions, and animist observations that the missionary Orientalists presumed was Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102_170-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999100–102-170">[140]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ronaldinden127_100-3"><a href="#cite_note-ronaldinden127-100">[81]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESweetman200414–15_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESweetman200414–15-171">[141]</a></sup> These reports influenced perceptions about Hinduism. Scholars such as Pennington state that the colonial polemical reports led to fabricated stereotypes where Hinduism was mere mystic paganism devoted to the service of devils,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-173"><a href="#cite_note-173">[note 20]</a></sup> while other scholars state that the colonial constructions influenced the belief that the <i>Vedas</i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Manusmriti" title="Manusmriti">Manusmriti</a></i> and such texts were the essence of Hindu religiosity, and in the modern association of 'Hindu doctrine' with the schools of Vedanta (in particular Advaita Vedanta) as a paradigmatic example of Hinduism's mystical nature".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKing1999169_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKing1999169-174">[143]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sweetman_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sweetman-175">[note 21]</a></sup> Pennington, while concurring that the study of Hinduism as a world religion began in the colonial era, disagrees that Hinduism is a colonial European era invention.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPennington2005pp._4–5_and_Chapter_6_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPennington2005pp._4–5_and_Chapter_6-176">[144]</a></sup> He states that the shared theology, common ritual grammar and way of life of those who identify themselves as Hindus is traceable to ancient times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPennington2005pp._4–5_and_Chapter_6_176-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPennington2005pp._4–5_and_Chapter_6-176">[144]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-183"><a href="#cite_note-183">[note 22]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Modern_India_and_the_world">Modern India and the world</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1712" data-file-width="2272" decoding="async" height="166" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG/220px-Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG/330px-Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f8/Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG/440px-Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hare_Krishna_in_Helsinki_H1118_C.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <a href="/wiki/International_Society_for_Krishna_Consciousness" title="International Society for Krishna Consciousness">Hare Krishna</a> group at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Esplanadi_Park" title="Esplanadi Park">Esplanadi Park</a> in <a href="/wiki/Helsinki" title="Helsinki">Helsinki, Finland</a></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Hindutva" title="Hindutva">Hindutva</a> movement has extensively argued for the unity of Hinduism, dismissing the differences and regarding India as a Hindu-country since ancient times.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-184"><a href="#cite_note-184">[151]</a></sup> And there are assumptions of political dominance of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_nationalism" title="Hindu nationalism">Hindu nationalism</a> in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, also known as <i>'Neo-Hindutva'</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-185"><a href="#cite_note-185">[152]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-186"><a href="#cite_note-186">[153]</a></sup> There have also been increase in pre-dominance of <a href="/wiki/Hindutva" title="Hindutva">Hindutva</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, similar to that of <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-187"><a href="#cite_note-187">[154]</a></sup> The scope of Hinduism is also increasing in the other parts of the world, due to the cultural influences such as <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hare_Krishna_movement" title="Hare Krishna movement">Hare Krishna movement</a> by many missionaries organisations, especially by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iskcon" title="Iskcon">Iskcon</a> and this is also due to the migration of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indian_Hindus" title="Indian Hindus">Indian Hindus</a> to the other nations of the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHatcher2015239_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHatcher2015239-188">[155]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-189"><a href="#cite_note-189">[156]</a></sup> Hinduism is growing fast in many <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_West" title="Hinduism in the West">western nations</a> and in some <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Africa" title="Hinduism in Africa">African nations</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ty78_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-ty78-192">[note 23]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Beliefs">Beliefs</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Halebid3.JPG"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/220px-Halebid3.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/330px-Halebid3.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2e/Halebid3.JPG/440px-Halebid3.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Halebid3.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Temple wall panel relief sculpture at the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hoysaleswara_temple" title="Hoysaleswara temple">Hoysaleswara temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Halebidu" title="Halebidu">Halebidu</a>, representing the <a href="/wiki/Trimurti" title="Trimurti">Trimurti</a>: <a href="/wiki/Brahma" title="Brahma">Brahma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a></div></div></div>
<p>Prominent themes in Hindu beliefs include (but are not restricted to) Dharma (ethics/duties), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samsara" title="Samsara"><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">saṃsāra</i></span></a> (the continuing cycle of entanglement in passions and the resulting birth, life, death, and rebirth), Karma (action, intent, and consequences), moksha (liberation from attachment and saṃsāra), and the various yogas (paths or practices).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003_27-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003-27">[20]</a></sup> However not all of these themes are found among the various different systems of Hindu beliefs. Beliefs in moksha or saṃsāra are absent in certain Hindu beliefs, and were also absent among early forms of Hinduism, which was characterized by a belief in an <a href="/wiki/Afterlife" title="Afterlife">Afterlife</a>, with traces of this still being found among various Hindu beliefs, such as <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81ddha" title="Śrāddha">Śrāddha</a>. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ancestor_worship" title="Ancestor worship">Ancestor worship</a> once formed an integral part of Hindu beliefs and is today still found as important element in various Folk Hindu streams.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-A.M._Boyer_1901_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-A.M._Boyer_1901-193">[159]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Yuvraj_Krishan_1997_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-Yuvraj_Krishan_1997-194">[160]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Laumakis_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-Laumakis-195">[161]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hayakawa_2014_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hayakawa_2014-196">[162]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sayers_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sayers-197">[163]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-repositories.lib.utexas.edu_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-repositories.lib.utexas.edu-198">[164]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Sayers_182–197_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-Sayers_182–197-199">[165]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Purusharthas">Purusharthas</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Puru%E1%B9%A3%C4%81rtha" title="Puruṣārtha">Puruṣārtha</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Diksha" title="Diksha">Diksha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kāma</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Moksha#Hinduism" title="Moksha">Mokṣa</a></div>
<p>Purusharthas refers to the objectives of human life. Classical Hindu thought accepts four proper goals or aims of human life, known as Puruṣārthas:<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Bilimoria_2007_p._103_24-1"><a href="#cite_note-Bilimoria_2007_p._103-24">[17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199711_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199711-25">[18]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a></li></ul>
<h4><span id="Dharma_.28righteousness.2C_ethics.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Dharma_(righteousness,_ethics)">Dharma (righteousness, ethics)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">Dharma</a></div>
<p>Dharma is considered the foremost goal of a human being in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-200"><a href="#cite_note-200">[166]</a></sup> The concept of dharma includes behaviors that are considered to be in accord with <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rta" title="Rta">rta</a>, the order that makes life and universe possible,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-201"><a href="#cite_note-201">[167]</a></sup> and includes duties, rights, laws, conduct, virtues and "right way of living".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tce_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-tce-202">[168]</a></sup> Hindu dharma includes the religious duties, moral rights and duties of each individual, as well as behaviors that enable social order, right conduct, and those that are virtuous.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-tce_202-1"><a href="#cite_note-tce-202">[168]</a></sup> Dharma, according to <a href="/wiki/J._A._B._van_Buitenen" title="J. A. B. van Buitenen">Van Buitenen</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanbuitenen_203-0"><a href="#cite_note-vanbuitenen-203">[169]</a></sup> is that which all existing beings must accept and respect to sustain harmony and order in the world. It is, states Van Buitenen, the pursuit and execution of one's nature and true calling, thus playing one's role in cosmic concert.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanbuitenen_203-1"><a href="#cite_note-vanbuitenen-203">[169]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brihadaranyaka" title="Brihadaranyaka">Brihadaranyaka Upanishad</a> states it as:
</p>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Nothing is higher than Dharma. The weak overcomes the stronger by Dharma, as over a king. Truly that Dharma is the Truth (<i>Satya</i>); Therefore, when a man speaks the Truth, they say, "He speaks the Dharma"; and if he speaks Dharma, they say, "He speaks the Truth!" For both are one.</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Brihadaranyaka_Upanishad" title="Brihadaranyaka Upanishad">Brihadaranyaka Upanishad</a>, 1.4.xiv<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[170]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-205"><a href="#cite_note-205">[171]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<p>In the <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a>, <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a> defines dharma as upholding both this-worldly and other-worldly affairs. (Mbh 12.110.11). The word <i>Sanātana</i> means <i>eternal</i>, <i>perennial</i>, or <i>forever</i>; thus, <i>Sanātana Dharma</i> signifies that it is the dharma that has neither beginning nor end.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-206"><a href="#cite_note-206">[172]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Artha_.28livelihood.2C_wealth.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Artha_(livelihood,_wealth)">Artha (livelihood, wealth)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">Artha</a></div>
<p>Artha is objective and virtuous pursuit of wealth for livelihood, obligations, and economic prosperity. It is inclusive of political life, diplomacy, and material well-being. The artha concept includes all "means of life", activities and resources that enables one to be in a state one wants to be in, wealth, career and financial security.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKoller1968_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKoller1968-207">[173]</a></sup> The proper pursuit of artha is considered an important aim of human life in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002a55–56_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002a55–56-208">[174]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bruces_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-bruces-209">[175]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="K.C4.81ma_.28sensual_pleasure.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Kāma_(sensual_pleasure)">Kāma (sensual pleasure)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">Kama</a></div>
<p>Kāma (Sanskrit, <a href="/wiki/Pali" title="Pali">Pali</a>: काम) means desire, wish, passion, longing, pleasure of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Senses" title="Senses">senses</a>, the aesthetic enjoyment of life, affection, or love, with or without sexual connotations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-210"><a href="#cite_note-210">[176]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-mmwse_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-mmwse-211">[177]</a></sup> In Hinduism, kama is considered an essential and healthy goal of human life when pursued without sacrificing dharma, artha and moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-212"><a href="#cite_note-212">[178]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Mok.E1.B9.A3a_.28liberation.2C_freedom_from_sa.E1.B9.83s.C4.81ra.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Mokṣa_(liberation,_freedom_from_saṃsāra)">Mokṣa (liberation, freedom from saṃsāra)</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">Moksha</a></div>
<p>Moksha (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a>: <span lang="sa">मोक्ष</span>, <small><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Romanization_of_Sanskrit" title="Romanization of Sanskrit">romanized</a>: </small><span title="Sanskrit-language romanization"><i lang="sa-Latn">mokṣa</i></span>) or <b>mukti</b> (Sanskrit: <span lang="sa">मुक्ति</span>) is the ultimate, most important goal in Hinduism. In one sense, moksha is a concept associated with liberation from sorrow, suffering and saṃsāra (birth-rebirth cycle). A release from this eschatological cycle, in after life, particularly in theistic schools of Hinduism is called moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vanbuitenen_203-2"><a href="#cite_note-vanbuitenen-203">[169]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERinehart200419–21_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERinehart200419–21-213">[179]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-214"><a href="#cite_note-214">[180]</a></sup> Due to belief in the indestructibility of Atman c.q. <i><a href="/wiki/Purusha" title="Purusha">purusha</a></i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-215"><a href="#cite_note-215">[181]</a></sup> death is deemed insignificant with respect to the cosmic Self.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-216"><a href="#cite_note-216">[182]</a></sup>
</p><p>The meaning of <i>moksha</i> differs among the various Hindu schools of thought. For example, Advaita Vedanta holds that after attaining moksha a person knows their essence, Self as pure consciousness or the witness-consciousness and identifies it as identical to Brahman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter-217">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klausklost_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-218">[184]</a></sup> The followers of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dvaita" title="Dvaita">Dvaita</a> (dualistic) schools, in moksha state, identify individual essence as distinct from Brahman but infinitesimally close, and after attaining moksha expect to spend eternity in a <a href="/wiki/Loka" title="Loka">loka</a> (heaven). To theistic schools of Hinduism, moksha is liberation from saṃsāra, while for other schools such as the monistic school, moksha is possible in current life and is a psychological concept.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutsch2001_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutsch2001-219">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter_217-1"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter-217">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-220"><a href="#cite_note-220">[186]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-danielingails_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-danielingails-221">[187]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klausklost_218-1"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-218">[184]</a></sup> According to Deutsch, moksha is transcendental consciousness to the latter, the perfect state of being, of self-realization, of freedom and of "realizing the whole universe as the Self".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDeutsch2001_219-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDeutsch2001-219">[185]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karlpotter_217-2"><a href="#cite_note-karlpotter-217">[183]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-danielingails_221-1"><a href="#cite_note-danielingails-221">[187]</a></sup> <i>Moksha</i> in these schools of Hinduism, suggests <a href="/wiki/Klaus_Klostermaier" title="Klaus Klostermaier">Klaus Klostermaier</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klausklost_218-2"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-218">[184]</a></sup> implies a setting free of hitherto fettered faculties, a removing of obstacles to an unrestricted life, permitting a person to be more truly a person in the full sense; the concept presumes an unused human potential of creativity, compassion and understanding which had been blocked and shut out. Moksha is more than liberation from life-rebirth cycle of suffering (saṃsāra); Vedantic school separates this into two:<i>Jivanmukti</i> (liberation in this life) and <i>Videhamukti</i> (liberation after death).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-klausklost_218-3"><a href="#cite_note-klausklost-218">[184]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-222"><a href="#cite_note-222">[188]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-223"><a href="#cite_note-223">[189]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Karma_and_sa.E1.B9.83s.C4.81ra"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Karma_and_saṃsāra">Karma and saṃsāra</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">Karma</a></div>
<p><i>Karma</i> translates literally as <i>action</i>, <i>work</i>, or <i>deed</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[190]</a></sup> and also refers to a Vedic theory of "moral law of cause and effect".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[191]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-226"><a href="#cite_note-226">[192]</a></sup> The theory is a combination of (1) causality that may be ethical or non-ethical; (2) ethicization, that is good or bad actions have consequences; and (3) rebirth.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wdointro_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-wdointro-227">[193]</a></sup> Karma theory is interpreted as explaining the present circumstances of an individual with reference to his or her actions in the past. These actions and their consequences may be in a person's current life, or, according to some schools of Hinduism, in past lives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wdointro_227-1"><a href="#cite_note-wdointro-227">[193]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-228"><a href="#cite_note-228">[194]</a></sup> This cycle of birth, life, death and rebirth is called <i><a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">saṃsāra</a></i>. Liberation from saṃsāra through moksha is believed to ensure lasting <a href="/wiki/%C4%80nanda_(Hindu_philosophy)" title="Ānanda (Hindu philosophy)">happiness</a> and <a href="/wiki/Peace#Hinduism" title="Peace">peace</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERadhakrishnan1996254_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERadhakrishnan1996254-229">[195]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-230"><a href="#cite_note-230">[196]</a></sup> Hindu scriptures teach that the future is both a function of current human effort derived from free will and past human actions that set the circumstances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-231"><a href="#cite_note-231">[197]</a></sup> The idea of <a href="/wiki/Reincarnation" title="Reincarnation">reincarnation</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83s%C4%81ra" title="Saṃsāra">saṃsāra</a>, is not mentioned in the early layers of historical Hindu texts such as the <i>Rigveda</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-232"><a href="#cite_note-232">[198]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-233"><a href="#cite_note-233">[199]</a></sup> The later layers of the <i>Rigveda</i> do mention ideas that suggest an approach towards the idea of rebirth, according to Ranade. 
<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELaumakis200890–99_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELaumakis200890–99-234">[200]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-235"><a href="#cite_note-235">[201]</a></sup> According to Sayers, these earliest layers of Hindu literature show ancestor worship and rites such as <i>sraddha</i> (offering food to the ancestors). The later Vedic texts such as the <i>Aranyakas</i> and the <i>Upanisads</i> show a different soteriology based on reincarnation, they show little concern with ancestor rites, and they begin to philosophically interpret the earlier rituals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-236"><a href="#cite_note-236">[202]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-237"><a href="#cite_note-237">[203]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-238"><a href="#cite_note-238">[204]</a></sup> The idea of reincarnation and karma have roots in the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> of the late <a href="/wiki/Vedic_period" title="Vedic period">Vedic period</a>, predating the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddha" title="Buddha">Buddha</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Mahavira" title="Mahavira">Mahavira</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-damienkeown32_239-0"><a href="#cite_note-damienkeown32-239">[205]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELaumakis2008_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELaumakis2008-240">[206]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Concept_of_God">Concept of God</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a> and <a href="/wiki/God_in_Hinduism" title="God in Hinduism">God in Hinduism</a></div>
<p>Hinduism is a diverse system of thought with a wide variety of beliefs;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lipner2009p8_80-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lipner2009p8-80">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-241"><a href="#cite_note-241">[207]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[web 12]</a></sup> its concept of God is complex and depends upon each individual and the tradition and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_philosophy" title="Hindu philosophy">philosophy</a> followed. It is sometimes referred to as <a href="/wiki/God_in_Hinduism" title="God in Hinduism">henotheistic</a> (i.e., involving devotion to a single god while accepting the existence of others), but any such term is an overgeneralization.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004xiv_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004xiv-243">[208]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-244"><a href="#cite_note-244">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1023981488">@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .rquote{width:auto!important;float:none!important}}</style><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r996844942" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><blockquote class="templatequote rquote" style="float: left; width: 33%;"><p>Who really knows?<br/>Who will here proclaim it? <br/>Whence was it produced? Whence is this creation?<br/>The gods came afterwards, with the creation of this universe.<br/>Who then knows whence it has arisen?</p><div class="templatequotecite">— <cite><a href="/wiki/Nasadiya_Sukta" title="Nasadiya Sukta">Nasadiya Sukta</a>, concerns the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Origin_of_the_universe" title="Origin of the universe">origin of the universe</a>, <a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a>, <i>10:129–6</i><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKramer1986[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidRzUAu-43W5oCpgPA34_34–]_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKramer1986[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidRzUAu-43W5oCpgPA34_34–]-245">[210]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChristian2011[httpsarchiveorgdetailsmapstimeintroduc00chri_515pagen46_18–]_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChristian2011[httpsarchiveorgdetailsmapstimeintroduc00chri_515pagen46_18–]-246">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESingh2008[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidH3lUIIYxWkECpgPA206_206–]_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESingh2008[httpsbooksgooglecombooksidH3lUIIYxWkECpgPA206_206–]-247">[212]</a></sup></cite></div></blockquote>
<p>The <i><a href="/wiki/Nasadiya_Sukta" title="Nasadiya Sukta">Nasadiya Sukta</a></i> (<i>Creation Hymn</i>) of the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rig_Veda" title="Rig Veda">Rig Veda</a></i> is one of the earliest texts<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996226_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996226-248">[213]</a></sup> which "demonstrates a sense of metaphysical speculation" about what created the universe, the concept of god(s) and The One, and whether even The One knows how the universe came into being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[214]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-3translations_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-3translations-250">[215]</a></sup> The <i>Rig Veda</i> praises various <a href="/wiki/Hindu_deities" title="Hindu deities">deities</a>, none superior nor inferior, in a henotheistic manner.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-251"><a href="#cite_note-251">[216]</a></sup> The hymns repeatedly refer to <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">One Truth and One Ultimate Reality</a>. The "One Truth" of <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic literature</a>, in modern era scholarship, has been interpreted as monotheism, monism, as well as a deified Hidden Principles behind the great happenings and processes of nature.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-252"><a href="#cite_note-252">[217]</a></sup>
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti">.mw-parser-output .tmulti .multiimageinner{display:flex;flex-direction:column}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{display:flex;flex-direction:row;clear:left;flex-wrap:wrap;width:100%;box-sizing:border-box}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{margin:1px;float:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .theader{clear:both;font-weight:bold;text-align:center;align-self:center;background-color:transparent;width:100%}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbcaption{background-color:transparent}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-left{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-right{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .text-align-center{text-align:center}@media all and (max-width:720px){.mw-parser-output .tmulti .thumbinner{width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:none!important;align-items:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow{justify-content:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle{float:none!important;max-width:100%!important;box-sizing:border-box;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .tsingle .thumbcaption{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .tmulti .trow>.thumbcaption{text-align:center}}</style><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader"><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Gods and Goddesses</a> in Hinduism</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:155px;max-width:155px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:203px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:MurudeshwarStatue.JPG"><img alt="Shiva" data-file-height="3648" data-file-width="2736" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/MurudeshwarStatue.JPG/153px-MurudeshwarStatue.JPG" //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/MurudeshwarStatue.JPG/306px-MurudeshwarStatue.JPG 2x" width="153"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:133px;max-width:133px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:203px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG"><img alt="Durga" data-file-height="3069" data-file-width="1973" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG/131px-Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG/197px-Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f5/Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG/262px-Durga_Mahisasuramardini.JPG 2x" width="131"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Durga" title="Durga">Durga</a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:150px;max-width:150px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:211px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right,_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg"><img alt="Lakshmi" data-file-height="3025" data-file-width="2112" decoding="async" height="212" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/148px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/222px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/49/A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg/296px-A_powerful_deity_in_her_own_right%2C_Shri_Lakshmi_herself.jpg 2x" width="148"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Lakshmi" title="Lakshmi">Lakshmi</a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:138px;max-width:138px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:211px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:God_Vishnu.jpg"><img alt="Vishnu" data-file-height="3167" data-file-width="2043" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/136px-God_Vishnu.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/204px-God_Vishnu.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/72/God_Vishnu.jpg/272px-God_Vishnu.jpg 2x" width="136"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Hindus believe that all living creatures have a Self. This true "Self" of every person, is called the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" title="Atman (Hinduism)">ātman</a></i>. The Self is believed to be eternal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams197420–37_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams197420–37-253">[218]</a></sup> According to the monistic/pantheistic (<a href="/wiki/Nondualism" title="Nondualism">non-dualist</a>) theologies of Hinduism (such as <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta school</a>), this <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">Atman</a> is indistinct from <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>, the supreme spirit or <a href="/wiki/Ultimate_reality" title="Ultimate reality">the Ultimate Reality</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bhaskaranandaessential_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaranandaessential-254">[219]</a></sup> The goal of life, according to the <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita school</a>, is to realise that <a href="/wiki/Jiva" title="Jiva">one's Self</a> is identical to <a href="/wiki/Paramatman" title="Paramatman">supreme Self</a>, that the supreme Self is present in everything and everyone, all life is interconnected and there is oneness in all life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVivekananda1987_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVivekananda1987-255">[220]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-256"><a href="#cite_note-256">[221]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-257"><a href="#cite_note-257">[222]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Dualism_(Indian_philosophy)" title="Dualism (Indian philosophy)">Dualistic</a> schools (<a href="/wiki/Dvaita_Vedanta" title="Dvaita Vedanta">Dvaita</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">Bhakti</a>) understand <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a> as a Supreme Being separate from <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">individual Selfs</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347-258">[223]</a></sup> They worship the Supreme Being variously as <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>, <a href="/wiki/Brahma" title="Brahma">Brahma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a>, or <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a>, depending upon the sect. God is called <i><a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavan" title="Bhagavan">Bhagavan</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Parameshwara_(god)" title="Parameshwara (god)">Parameshwara</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Deva</a></i> or <i><a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a></i>, and these terms have different meanings in different schools of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEliade200973–76_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEliade200973–76-259">[224]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERadhakrishnanMoore196737–39,_401–403,_498–503_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERadhakrishnanMoore196737–39,_401–403,_498–503-260">[225]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams2001_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams2001-261">[226]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hindu texts accept a polytheistic framework, but this is generally conceptualized as the divine essence or luminosity that gives vitality and animation to the inanimate natural substances.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-262">[227]</a></sup> There is a divine in everything, human beings, animals, trees and rivers. It is observable in offerings to rivers, trees, tools of one's work, animals and birds, rising sun, friends and guests, teachers and parents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_262-1"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-262">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-263"><a href="#cite_note-263">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-264"><a href="#cite_note-264">[229]</a></sup> It is the divine in these that makes each sacred and worthy of reverence, rather than them being sacred in and of themselves. This perception of divinity manifested in all things, as Buttimer and Wallin view it, makes the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic</a> foundations of Hinduism quite distinct from <a href="/wiki/Animism" title="Animism">animism</a>, in which all things are themselves divine.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_262-2"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-262">[227]</a></sup> The animistic premise sees multiplicity, and therefore an equality of ability to compete for power when it comes to man and man, man and animal, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Man_and_nature" title="Man and nature">man and nature</a>, etc. The <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic</a> view does not perceive this competition, equality of man to nature, or multiplicity so much as an overwhelming and interconnecting single divinity that unifies everyone and everything.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Wallin1999p64_262-3"><a href="#cite_note-Wallin1999p64-262">[227]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[230]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-266"><a href="#cite_note-266">[231]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">Hindu scriptures</a> name celestial entities called <i><a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">Devas</a></i> (or <i><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a></i></span></i> in feminine form), which may be translated into English as <i>gods</i> or <i>heavenly beings</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-267"><a href="#cite_note-267">[note 24]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Deva_(Hinduism)" title="Deva (Hinduism)">devas</a> are an integral part of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_culture" title="Hindu culture">Hindu culture</a> and are depicted in art, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_architecture" title="Hindu architecture">architecture</a> and through <a href="/wiki/Hindu_iconography" title="Hindu iconography">icons</a>, and stories about them are related in the scriptures, particularly in Indian epic poetry and the <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>. They are, however, often distinguished from <a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a>, a personal god, with many Hindus worshipping <a href="/wiki/Ishvara" title="Ishvara">Ishvara</a> in one of its particular manifestations as their <i><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/I%E1%B9%A3%E1%B9%ADa_devat%C4%81" title="Iṣṭa devatā">iṣṭa devatā</a></i></span></i>, or chosen ideal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner20059,_15,_49,_54,_86_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner20059,_15,_49,_54,_86-268">[232]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERenou196455_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERenou196455-269">[233]</a></sup> The choice is a matter of individual preference,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harman1_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-harman1-270">[234]</a></sup> and of regional and family traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-harman1_270-1"><a href="#cite_note-harman1-270">[234]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[note 25]</a></sup> The multitude of Devas are considered manifestations of Brahman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avatars_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-avatars-273">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1185" data-file-width="1280" decoding="async" height="204" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg/220px-Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg/330px-Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b9/Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg/440px-Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Vishnu_Surrounded_by_his_Avatars.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Hindu god <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a> (centre) surrounded by his <a href="/wiki/Dashavatara" title="Dashavatara">ten major avatars</a>, namely <a href="/wiki/Matsya" title="Matsya">Matsya</a>; <a href="/wiki/Kurma" title="Kurma">Kurma</a>; <a href="/wiki/Varaha" title="Varaha">Varaha</a>; <a href="/wiki/Narasimha" title="Narasimha">Narasimha</a>; <a href="/wiki/Vamana" title="Vamana">Vamana</a>; <a href="/wiki/Parashurama" title="Parashurama">Parashurama</a>; <a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">Rama</a>; <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a>; <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Buddha_in_Hinduism" title="Buddha in Hinduism">Buddha</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Kalki" title="Kalki">Kalki</a></div></div></div>
<p>The word <i><a href="/wiki/Avatar" title="Avatar">avatar</a></i> does not appear in the <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic literature</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-274"><a href="#cite_note-274">[237]</a></sup> but appears in verb forms in post-Vedic literature, and as a noun particularly in the Puranic literature after the 6th century CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-275"><a href="#cite_note-275">[238]</a></sup> Theologically, the reincarnation idea is most often associated with the <i>avatars</i> of Hindu god <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>, though the idea has been applied to other deities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-276"><a href="#cite_note-276">[239]</a></sup> Varying lists of avatars of Vishnu appear in Hindu scriptures, including the ten <a href="/wiki/Dashavatara" title="Dashavatara">Dashavatara</a> of the <i><a href="/wiki/Garuda_Purana" title="Garuda Purana">Garuda Purana</a></i> and the twenty-two avatars in the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavata_Purana" title="Bhagavata Purana">Bhagavata Purana</a></i>, though the latter adds that the incarnations of Vishnu are innumerable.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryant200718_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryant200718-277">[240]</a></sup> The avatars of Vishnu are important in Vaishnavism theology. In the goddess-based <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism tradition</a>, avatars of the <a href="/wiki/Devi" title="Devi">Devi</a> are found and all goddesses are considered to be different aspects of the same <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">metaphysical Brahman</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-278"><a href="#cite_note-278">[241]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Shakti" title="Shakti">Shakti</a> <i>(energy)</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-279"><a href="#cite_note-279">[242]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-280"><a href="#cite_note-280">[243]</a></sup> While avatars of other deities such as <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> and Shiva are also mentioned in medieval Hindu texts, this is minor and occasional.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-281"><a href="#cite_note-281">[244]</a></sup>
</p><p>Both theistic and atheistic ideas, for epistemological and metaphysical reasons, are profuse in different schools of Hinduism. The early <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a> school of Hinduism, for example, was non-theist/atheist,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-282"><a href="#cite_note-282">[245]</a></sup> but later <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a> school scholars argued that God exists and offered proofs using its theory of logic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-283"><a href="#cite_note-283">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-284"><a href="#cite_note-284">[247]</a></sup> Other schools disagreed with Nyaya scholars. <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-285"><a href="#cite_note-285">[248]</a></sup> Mimamsa<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coward2008p114_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-Coward2008p114-286">[249]</a></sup> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Carvaka" title="Carvaka">Carvaka</a> schools of Hinduism, were non-theist/atheist, arguing that "God was an unnecessary metaphysical assumption".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-287"><a href="#cite_note-287">[web 13]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESen_Gupta1986viii_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESen_Gupta1986viii-288">[250]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-289"><a href="#cite_note-289">[251]</a></sup> Its <a href="/wiki/Vaisheshika" title="Vaisheshika">Vaisheshika</a> school started as another non-theistic tradition relying on naturalism and that all matter is eternal, but it later introduced the concept of a non-creator God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[252]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-291"><a href="#cite_note-291">[253]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007337–338_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007337–338-292">[254]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Raja_yoga" title="Raja yoga">Yoga</a> school of Hinduism accepted the concept of a "personal god" and left it to the Hindu to define his or her god.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-293"><a href="#cite_note-293">[255]</a></sup> Advaita Vedanta taught a monistic, abstract Self and Oneness in everything, with no room for gods or deity, a perspective that Mohanty calls, "spiritual, not religious".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-294"><a href="#cite_note-294">[256]</a></sup> Bhakti sub-schools of Vedanta taught a creator God that is distinct from each human being.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347_258-1"><a href="#cite_note-R_Prasad_2009_pages_345-347-258">[223]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1600" data-file-width="1459" decoding="async" height="241" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg/220px-Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg/330px-Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d8/Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg/440px-Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Khajuraho_Ardharnareshvar.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ardhanarishvara" title="Ardhanarishvara">Ardhanarishvara</a>, showing both feminine and masculine aspect of god in Hinduism.</div></div></div>
<p>God in Hinduism is often represented, having both the <a href="/wiki/God_and_gender_in_Hinduism" title="God and gender in Hinduism">feminine and masculine</a> aspects. The notion of the feminine in deity is much more pronounced and is evident in the pairings of Shiva with Parvati (<a href="/wiki/Ardhanarishvara" title="Ardhanarishvara">Ardhanarishvara</a>), <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a> accompanied by Lakshmi, <a href="/wiki/Radha" title="Radha">Radha</a> with <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Krishna</a> and <a href="/wiki/Sita" title="Sita">Sita</a> with <a href="/wiki/Rama" title="Rama">Rama</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[257]</a></sup>
</p><p>According to <a href="/wiki/Graham_Schweig" title="Graham Schweig">Graham Schweig</a>, Hinduism has the strongest presence of the divine feminine in world religion from ancient times to the present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryant2007441_296-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryant2007441-296">[258]</a></sup> The goddess is viewed as the heart of the most esoteric <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Saiva traditions</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood2003200–203_297-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood2003200–203-297">[259]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Authority">Authority</span></h3>
<p><span class="anchor" id="Questioning_authority"></span>
Authority and eternal truths play an important role in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-0"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> Religious traditions and truths are believed to be contained in its sacred texts, which are accessed and taught by sages, gurus, saints or avatars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-1"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> But there is also a strong tradition of the questioning of authority, internal debate and challenging of religious texts in Hinduism. The Hindus believe that this deepens the understanding of the eternal truths and further develops the tradition. Authority "was mediated through [...] an intellectual culture that tended to develop ideas collaboratively, and according to the shared logic of natural reason."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-2"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> Narratives in the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a> present characters questioning persons of authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-3"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Kena_Upanishad" title="Kena Upanishad">Kena Upanishad</a> repeatedly asks <i>kena</i>, 'by what' power something is the case.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-4"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Katha_Upanishad" title="Katha Upanishad">Katha Upanishad</a> and Bhagavad Gita present narratives where the student criticizes the teacher's inferior answers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-5"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Shiva_Purana" title="Shiva Purana">Shiva Purana</a>, Shiva questions Vishnu and Brahma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-6"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> Doubt plays a repeated role in the Mahabharata.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-7"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Jayadeva" title="Jayadeva">Jayadeva</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Gita_Govinda" title="Gita Govinda">Gita Govinda</a> presents criticism via the character of <a href="/wiki/Radha" title="Radha">Radha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-frazier1415_298-8"><a href="#cite_note-frazier1415-298">[260]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Main_traditions">Main traditions</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Denominations">Denominations</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_denominations" title="Hindu denominations">Hindu denominations</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="594" decoding="async" height="296" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/220px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/330px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/07/Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg/440px-Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Ganesha_pachayatana.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A Ganesha-centric <a href="/wiki/Panchayatana_puja" title="Panchayatana puja">Panchayatana</a> ("five deities", from the Smarta tradition): <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a> (centre) with <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> (top left), <a href="/wiki/Parvati" title="Parvati">Parvati</a> (top right), <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a> (bottom left) and <a href="/wiki/Surya" title="Surya">Surya</a> (bottom right). All these deities also have separate sects dedicated to them.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Prambanan_Java245.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1753" data-file-width="2585" decoding="async" height="149" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Prambanan_Java245.jpg/220px-Prambanan_Java245.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Prambanan_Java245.jpg/330px-Prambanan_Java245.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Prambanan_Java245.jpg/440px-Prambanan_Java245.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Prambanan_Java245.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The great <a href="/wiki/Prambanan" title="Prambanan">Prambanan</a> Hindu temple complex built in the 9th century, <a href="/wiki/Java" title="Java">Java</a>, Indonesia.</div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism has no central doctrinal authority and many practising Hindus do not claim to belong to any particular denomination or tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner200513,_45_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner200513,_45-299">[261]</a></sup> Four major denominations are, however, used in scholarly studies: <i>Shaivism</i>, <i>Shaktism</i>, <i>Smartism</i> and <i>Vaishnavism</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhandarkar1913_47-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhandarkar1913-47">[34]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETattwanandan.d._48-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETattwanandan.d.-48">[35]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168_49-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113,_134,_155–161,_167–168-49">[36]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner2009377,_398_50-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner2009377,_398-50">[37]</a></sup> The followers of Vaishnavas are far the large majority of Hindus; the second large community are the Shaivites.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim2013400_300-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim2013400-300">[262]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHillerbrand2004906_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHillerbrand2004906-301">[263]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERosen201715,_note_28_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERosen201715,_note_28-302">[264]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007199_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007199-303">[265]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-305"><a href="#cite_note-305">[note 26]</a></sup> These denominations differ primarily in the central deity worshipped, the traditions and the <a href="/wiki/Soteriology" title="Soteriology">soteriological</a> outlook.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-306">[267]</a></sup> The denominations of Hinduism, states Lipner, are unlike those found in major religions of the world, because Hindu denominations are fuzzy with individuals practicing more than one, and he suggests the term "Hindu polycentrism".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELipner2009371–375_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELipner2009371–375-307">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vaishnavism is the devotional religious tradition that worships Vishnu<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-309"><a href="#cite_note-309">[note 27]</a></sup> and his avatars, particularly Krishna and Rama.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand201315–17_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand201315–17-310">[270]</a></sup> The adherents of this sect are generally non-ascetic, monastic, oriented towards community events and devotionalism practices inspired by "intimate loving, joyous, playful" <i>Krishna</i> and other Vishnu avatars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_306-1"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-306">[267]</a></sup> These practices sometimes include community dancing, singing of <a href="/wiki/Kirtan" title="Kirtan">Kirtans</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajans</a>, with sound and music believed by some to have meditative and spiritual powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand200438–43_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand200438–43-311">[271]</a></sup> Temple worship and festivals are typically elaborate in Vaishnavism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-312"><a href="#cite_note-312">[272]</a></sup> The Bhagavad Gita and the Ramayana, along with Vishnu-oriented Puranas provide its theistic foundations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-313"><a href="#cite_note-313">[273]</a></sup> Philosophically, their beliefs are rooted in the dualism sub-schools of Vedantic Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand201340–43_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand201340–43-314">[274]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryant2007357–358_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryant2007357–358-315">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>Shaivism is the tradition that focuses on Shiva. Shaivas are more attracted to ascetic individualism, and it has several sub-schools.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_306-2"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-306">[267]</a></sup> Their practices include bhakti-style devotionalism, yet their beliefs lean towards nondual, monistic schools of Hinduism such as Advaita and Raja Yoga.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-316">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand200438–43_311-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBryantEkstrand200438–43-311">[271]</a></sup> Some Shaivas worship in temples, while others emphasize yoga, striving to be one with Shiva within.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDalal2010209_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDalal2010209-317">[277]</a></sup> Avatars are uncommon, and some Shaivas visualize god as half male, half female, as a fusion of the male and female principles (<a href="/wiki/Ardhanarishvara" title="Ardhanarishvara">Ardhanarishvara</a>). Shaivism is related to Shaktism, wherein Shakti is seen as spouse of Shiva.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_316-1"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-316">[276]</a></sup> Community celebrations include festivals, and participation, with Vaishnavas, in pilgrimages such as the <a href="/wiki/Kumbh_Mela" title="Kumbh Mela">Kumbh Mela</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-318"><a href="#cite_note-318">[278]</a></sup> Shaivism has been more commonly practiced in the Himalayan north from Kashmir to Nepal, and in south India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIsaeva1995141–145_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaeva1995141–145-319">[279]</a></sup>
</p><p>Shaktism focuses on goddess worship of Shakti or Devi as cosmic mother,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sskumar_306-3"><a href="#cite_note-sskumar-306">[267]</a></sup> and it is particularly common in northeastern and eastern states of India such as <a href="/wiki/Assam" title="Assam">Assam</a> and <a href="/wiki/West_Bengal" title="West Bengal">Bengal</a>. Devi is depicted as in gentler forms like <a href="/wiki/Parvati" title="Parvati">Parvati</a>, the consort of Shiva; or, as fierce warrior goddesses like <a href="/wiki/Kali" title="Kali">Kali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Durga" title="Durga">Durga</a>. Followers of Shaktism recognize Shakti as the power that underlies the male principle. Shaktism is also associated with <a href="/wiki/Tantra" title="Tantra">Tantra</a> practices.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-320"><a href="#cite_note-320">[280]</a></sup> Community celebrations include festivals, some of which include processions and idol immersion into sea or other water bodies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-321"><a href="#cite_note-321">[281]</a></sup>
</p><p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Smartism" title="Smartism">Smartism</a> centers its worship simultaneously on all the major <a href="/wiki/Hindu_deities" title="Hindu deities">Hindu deities</a>: Shiva, Vishnu, Shakti, Ganesha, <a href="/wiki/Surya" title="Surya">Surya</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kartikeya" title="Kartikeya">Skanda</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996113-322">[282]</a></sup> The Smarta tradition developed during the (early) Classical Period of Hinduism around the beginning of the Common Era, when Hinduism emerged from the interaction between Brahmanism and local traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel2013_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel2013-323">[283]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood1996_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood1996-324">[284]</a></sup> The Smarta tradition is aligned with Advaita Vedanta, and regards <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a> as its founder or reformer, who considered worship of God-with-attributes (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saguna_Brahman" title="Saguna Brahman">Saguna Brahman</a>) as a journey towards ultimately realizing God-without-attributes (nirguna Brahman, Atman, Self-knowledge).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-williamw_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-williamw-325">[285]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-326"><a href="#cite_note-326">[286]</a></sup> The term <i>Smartism</i> is derived from Smriti texts of Hinduism, meaning those who remember the traditions in the texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_316-2"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-316">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-williamsonp89_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-williamsonp89-327">[287]</a></sup> This Hindu sect practices a philosophical Jnana yoga, scriptural studies, reflection, meditative path seeking an understanding of Self's oneness with God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-lancenelson_316-3"><a href="#cite_note-lancenelson-316">[276]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-328"><a href="#cite_note-328">[288]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are no census data available on demographic history or trends for the traditions within Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-329"><a href="#cite_note-329">[289]</a></sup> Estimates vary on the relative number of adherents in the different traditions of Hinduism. According to a 2010 estimate by Johnson and Grim, the Vaishnavism tradition is the largest group with about 641 million or 67.6% of Hindus, followed by Shaivism with 252 million or 26.6%, Shaktism with 30 million or 3.2% and other traditions including Neo-Hinduism and Reform Hinduism with 25 million or 2.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim2013400_300-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJohnsonGrim2013400-300">[262]</a></sup> In contrast, according to Jones and Ryan, Shaivism is the largest tradition of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2007474_304-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan2007474-304">[266]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Ethnicities">Ethnicities</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_South_Asia" title="Hinduism in South Asia">Hinduism in South Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Southeast_Asia" title="Hinduism in Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Balinese_Hinduism" title="Balinese Hinduism">Bali</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Java" title="Hinduism in Java">Java</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Vietnam" title="Hinduism in Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_West" title="Hinduism in the West">West</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="638" data-file-width="960" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg/220px-A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg/330px-A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg/440px-A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:A_Russian_Hindu_girl.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Russia" title="Hinduism in Russia">Russian Hindu</a> girl</div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism is traditionally a multi- or <a href="/wiki/Polyethnicity" title="Polyethnicity">polyethnic</a> religion. On the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a>, it is widespread among many <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_peoples" title="Indo-Aryan peoples">Indo-Aryan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dravidian_peoples" title="Dravidian peoples">Dravidian</a> and other <a href="/wiki/South_Asian_ethnic_groups" title="South Asian ethnic groups">South Asian ethnic groups</a>, for example, the <a href="/wiki/Meitei_people" title="Meitei people">Meitei people</a> (<a href="/wiki/Tibeto-Burman_languages" title="Tibeto-Burman languages">Tibeto-Burman</a> ethnicity in the northeastern Indian state <a href="/wiki/Manipur" title="Manipur">Manipur</a>).
</p><p>In addition, in antiquity and the <a href="/wiki/Middle_Ages" title="Middle Ages">Middle Ages</a>, Hinduism was the <a href="/wiki/State_religion" title="State religion">state religion</a> in many Indianized kingdoms of Asia, the <i><a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">Greater India</a></i> – from Afghanistan (<a href="/wiki/Kabul" title="Kabul">Kabul</a>) in the West and including almost all of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> in the East (<a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vietnam" title="Vietnam">Vietnam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Indonesia" title="Indonesia">Indonesia</a>, partly <a href="/wiki/Philippines" title="Philippines">Philippines</a>) – and only by 15th century was nearly everywhere supplanted by Buddhism and Islam,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECœdès1968Pande2006AcriCreeseGriffiths2011_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECœdès1968Pande2006AcriCreeseGriffiths2011-330">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-spread_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-spread-331">[291]</a></sup> except several still Hindu minor <a href="/wiki/Austronesian_peoples" title="Austronesian peoples">Austronesian</a> ethnic groups, such as the <a href="/wiki/Balinese_people" title="Balinese people">Balinese</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHowe2001Stuart-Fox2002_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHowe2001Stuart-Fox2002-332">[292]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gonda_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-Gonda-333">[293]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Tenggerese_people" title="Tenggerese people">Tenggerese people</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHefner1989KinneyKlokkeKieven2003_334-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHefner1989KinneyKlokkeKieven2003-334">[294]</a></sup> in Indonesia, and the <a href="/wiki/Chams" title="Chams">Chams</a> in Vietnam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPhuongLockhart2011Pande2006231_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPhuongLockhart2011Pande2006231-335">[295]</a></sup> Also, a small community of the Afghan <a href="/wiki/Pashtuns" title="Pashtuns">Pashtuns</a> who migrated to India after <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">partition</a> remain committed to Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[296]</a></sup>
</p><p>There are many new ethnic <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Ghana" title="Hinduism in Ghana">Ghanaian Hindus</a> in Ghana, who have converted to Hinduism due to the works of <a href="/wiki/Swami_Ghanananda_(Ghana)" title="Swami Ghanananda (Ghana)">Swami Ghananand Saraswati</a> and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_Monastery_of_Africa" title="Hindu Monastery of Africa">Hindu Monastery of Africa</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Joshi_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-Joshi-337">[297]</a></sup> From the beginning of the 20th century, by the forces of Baba Premananda Bharati (1858–1914), <a href="/wiki/Swami_Vivekananda" title="Swami Vivekananda">Swami Vivekananda</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/A.C._Bhaktivedanta_Swami_Prabhupada" title="A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada">A.C. Bhaktivedanta Swami Prabhupada</a> and other missionaries, Hinduism gained a certain distribution among the Western peoples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECarney2020_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECarney2020-338">[298]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Scriptures">Scriptures</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/%C5%9Aruti" title="Śruti">Śruti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Smriti" title="Smriti">Smriti</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hindu_texts" title="List of Hindu texts">List of Hindu texts</a>, and <a href="/wiki/%C5%9A%C4%81stra_pram%C4%81%E1%B9%87am_in_Hinduism" title="Śāstra pramāṇam in Hinduism">Śāstra pramāṇam in Hinduism</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1056" data-file-width="1100" decoding="async" height="211" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/220px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/330px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/02/Rigveda_MS2097.jpg/440px-Rigveda_MS2097.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Rigveda_MS2097.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i> is the first among four Vedas<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-339"><a href="#cite_note-339">[note 28]</a></sup> and is one of the oldest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Religious_texts" title="Religious texts">religious texts</a>. This Rigveda <a href="/wiki/Manuscript" title="Manuscript">manuscript</a> is in <a href="/wiki/Devanagari" title="Devanagari">Devanagari</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>The ancient scriptures of Hinduism are in Sanskrit. These texts are classified into two: Shruti and Smriti. Shruti is <i><a href="/wiki/Apauru%E1%B9%A3ey%C4%81" title="Apauruṣeyā">apauruṣeyā</a></i>, "not made of a man" but revealed to the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rishis" title="Rishis">rishis</a></i> (seers), and regarded as having the highest authority, while the smriti are manmade and have secondary authority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMuesse2011202_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMuesse2011202-340">[299]</a></sup> They are the two highest <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sources_of_dharma" title="Sources of dharma">sources of dharma</a>, the other two being <i><a href="/wiki/%C4%80c%C4%81ra" title="Ācāra">Śiṣṭa Āchāra/Sadāchara</a></i> (conduct of noble people) and finally <i><a href="/wiki/Atmatusti" title="Atmatusti">Ātma tuṣṭi</a></i> ("what is pleasing to oneself")<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-342"><a href="#cite_note-342">[note 29]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hindu scriptures were composed, memorized and transmitted verbally, across generations, for many centuries before they were written down.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood200368–69See_[[Michael_Witzel]]_quote_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood200368–69See_[[Michael_Witzel]]_quote-343">[300]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESargeantChapple19843_344-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESargeantChapple19843-344">[301]</a></sup> Over many centuries, sages refined the teachings and expanded the Shruti and Smriti, as well as developed Shastras with epistemological and metaphysical theories of six classical schools of Hinduism.
</p><p><i>Shruti</i> (lit. that which is heard)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERinehart200468_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERinehart200468-345">[302]</a></sup> primarily refers to the <i>Vedas</i>, which form the earliest record of the Hindu scriptures, and are regarded as eternal truths revealed to the ancient sages (<i><a href="/wiki/Rishi" title="Rishi">rishis</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood20084_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood20084-346">[303]</a></sup> There are four <i>Vedas</i> – <i><a href="/wiki/Rigveda" title="Rigveda">Rigveda</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Samaveda" title="Samaveda">Samaveda</a></i>, <i><a href="/wiki/Yajurveda" title="Yajurveda">Yajurveda</a></i> and <i><a href="/wiki/Atharvaveda" title="Atharvaveda">Atharvaveda</a></i>.
