Each Veda has been subclassified into four major text types – the <a href="/wiki/Samhita" title="Samhita">Samhitas</a> (mantras and benedictions), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Aranyakas" title="Aranyakas">Aranyakas</a> (text on rituals, ceremonies, sacrifices and symbolic-sacrifices), the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Brahmanas" title="Brahmanas">Brahmanas</a> (commentaries on rituals, ceremonies and sacrifices), and the Upanishads (text discussing meditation, philosophy and spiritual knowledge).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199635–39_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199635–39-347">[304]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-348"><a href="#cite_note-348">[305]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-349"><a href="#cite_note-349">[306]</a></sup> The first two parts of the Vedas were subsequently called the <i><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">Karmakāṇḍa</i></span></i> (ritualistic portion), while the last two form the <i><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">Jñānakāṇḍa</i></span></i> (knowledge portion, discussing spiritual insight and philosophical teachings).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-350"><a href="#cite_note-350">[307]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWerner200510,_58,_66_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWerner200510,_58,_66-351">[308]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams197425–41_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams197425–41-352">[309]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olivelle1998Introduction_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-Olivelle1998Introduction-353">[310]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Upanishads are the foundation of Hindu philosophical thought, and have profoundly influenced diverse traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wendydoniger_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-wendydoniger-354">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-355"><a href="#cite_note-355">[312]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-McDowell_181-1"><a href="#cite_note-McDowell-181">[149]</a></sup> Of the Shrutis (Vedic corpus), they alone are widely influential among Hindus, considered scriptures par excellence of Hinduism, and their central ideas have continued to influence its thoughts and traditions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-wendydoniger_354-1"><a href="#cite_note-wendydoniger-354">[311]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olivelle2014p3q_179-1"><a href="#cite_note-Olivelle2014p3q-179">[147]</a></sup> Sarvepalli Radhakrishnan states that the Upanishads have played a dominating role ever since their appearance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-356"><a href="#cite_note-356">[313]</a></sup> There are 108 <a href="/wiki/Muktik%C4%81" title="Muktikā">Muktikā</a> Upanishads in Hinduism, of which between 10 and 13 are variously counted by scholars as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mukhya_Upanishads" title="Mukhya Upanishads">Principal Upanishads</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Olivelle1998Introduction_353-1"><a href="#cite_note-Olivelle1998Introduction-353">[310]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-357"><a href="#cite_note-357">[314]</a></sup>
The most notable of the Smritis ("remembered") are the Hindu epics and the <i>Puranas</i>. The epics consist of the <i>Mahabharata</i> and the <i>Ramayana</i>. The <i>Bhagavad Gita</i> is an integral part of the <i>Mahabharata</i> and one of the most popular sacred texts of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-358"><a href="#cite_note-358">[315]</a></sup> It is sometimes called <i>Gitopanishad</i>, then placed in the Shruti ("heard") category, being Upanishadic in content.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-359"><a href="#cite_note-359">[316]</a></sup> The <i>Puranas</i>, which started to be composed from c. 300 CE onward,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999655_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen1999655-360">[317]</a></sup> contain extensive mythologies, and are central in the distribution of common themes of Hinduism through vivid narratives. The <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras" title="Yoga Sutras">Yoga Sutras</a></i> is a classical text for the Hindu Yoga tradition, which gained a renewed popularity in the 20th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-361"><a href="#cite_note-361">[318]</a></sup>
Since the 19th-century Indian modernists have re-asserted the 'Aryan origins' of Hinduism, "purifying" Hinduism from its Tantric elements<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233_120-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELorenzen200233-120">[95]</a></sup> and elevating the Vedic elements. Hindu modernists like Vivekananda see the Vedas as the laws of the spiritual world, which would still exist even if they were not revealed to the sages.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVivekananda19876–7Volume_I_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVivekananda19876–7Volume_I-362">[319]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarshananda1989_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarshananda1989-363">[320]</a></sup> In Tantric tradition, the <i>Agamas</i> refer to authoritative scriptures or the teachings of Shiva to Shakti,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200713_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200713-364">[321]</a></sup> while <i>Nigamas</i> refers to the Vedas and the teachings of Shakti to Shiva.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200713_364-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJonesRyan200713-364">[321]</a></sup> In Agamic schools of Hinduism, the Vedic literature and the Agamas are equally authoritative.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-365"><a href="#cite_note-365">[322]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-366"><a href="#cite_note-366">[323]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Practices">Practices</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Rituals">Rituals</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Arti_(Hinduism)" title="Arti (Hinduism)">Arti (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Abhisheka" title="Abhisheka">Abhisheka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">Japa</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Havan" title="Havan">Havan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">Yajna</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_wedding" title="Hindu wedding">Hindu wedding</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:(A)_Hindu_wedding,_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1728" data-file-width="2304" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/220px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/330px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/69/%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg/440px-%28A%29_Hindu_wedding%2C_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:(A)_Hindu_wedding,_Saptapadi_ritual_before_Agni_Yajna.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A wedding is the most extensive personal ritual an adult Hindu undertakes in his or her life. A typical <a href="/wiki/Hindu_wedding" title="Hindu wedding">Hindu wedding</a> is solemnized before Vedic <a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">fire</a> ritual (shown).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002a427_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002a427-367">[324]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Most Hindus observe <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">religious rituals at home</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-368"><a href="#cite_note-368">[325]</a></sup> The rituals vary greatly among regions, villages, and individuals. They are not mandatory in Hinduism. The nature and place of rituals is an individual's choice. Some devout Hindus perform daily rituals such as worshiping at dawn after bathing (usually at a family shrine, and typically includes lighting a lamp and offering foodstuffs before the images of deities), recitation from religious scripts, singing bhajans (devotional hymns), yoga, <a href="/wiki/Meditation" title="Meditation">meditation</a>, chanting mantras and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden1996145–146_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden1996145–146-369">[326]</a></sup>
</p><p>Vedic rituals of fire-oblation (<i><a href="/wiki/Yajna" title="Yajna">yajna</a></i>) and chanting of Vedic hymns are observed on special occasions, such as a Hindu wedding.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-370"><a href="#cite_note-370">[327]</a></sup> Other major life-stage events, such as rituals after death, include the <i>yajña</i> and chanting of Vedic <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">mantras</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-371"><a href="#cite_note-371">[web 15]</a></sup>
</p><p>The words of the mantras are "themselves sacred,"<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996346–347_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996346–347-372">[328]</a></sup> and "do not constitute <a href="/wiki/Speech_act" title="Speech act">linguistic utterances</a>."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996347_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996347-373">[329]</a></sup> Instead, as Klostermaier notes, in their application in Vedic rituals they become <a href="/wiki/Magic_(supernatural)" title="Magic (supernatural)">magical</a> sounds, "means to an end."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-374"><a href="#cite_note-374">[note 30]</a></sup> In the Brahmanical perspective, the sounds have their own meaning, mantras are considered "primordial rhythms of creation", preceding the forms to which they refer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996347_373-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996347-373">[329]</a></sup> By reciting them the cosmos is regenerated, "by enlivening and nourishing the forms of creation at their base. As long as the purity of the sounds is preserved, the recitation of the <i>mantras</i> will be efficacious, irrespective of whether their discursive meaning is understood by human beings."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996347_373-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHoldrege1996347-373">[329]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Coward2008p114_286-1"><a href="#cite_note-Coward2008p114-286">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Life-cycle_rites_of_passage">Life-cycle rites of passage</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83sk%C4%81ra" title="Saṃskāra">Saṃskāra</a></div>
<p>Major life stage milestones are celebrated as <i>sanskara</i> (<i>saṃskāra</i>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rites_of_passage" title="Rites of passage">rites of passage</a>) in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pandey_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-pandey-375">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-knipe_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-knipe-376">[331]</a></sup> The rites of passage are not mandatory, and vary in details by gender, community and regionally.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-377">[332]</a></sup> Gautama <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dharmasutra" title="Dharmasutra">Dharmasutras</a> composed in about the middle of 1st millennium BCE lists 48 sanskaras,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-patrick_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-patrick-378">[333]</a></sup> while <a href="/wiki/Kalpa_(Vedanga)" title="Kalpa (Vedanga)">Gryhasutra</a> and other texts composed centuries later list between 12 and 16 sanskaras.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pandey_375-1"><a href="#cite_note-pandey-375">[330]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-carlolson_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-carlolson-379">[334]</a></sup> The list of sanskaras in Hinduism include both external rituals such as those marking a baby's birth and a baby's name giving ceremony, as well as inner rites of resolutions and ethics such as <a href="/wiki/Compassion#Hinduism" title="Compassion">compassion</a> towards all living beings and positive attitude.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-patrick_378-1"><a href="#cite_note-patrick-378">[333]</a></sup>
The major traditional rites of passage in Hinduism include<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_377-1"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-377">[332]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Garbhadhana" title="Garbhadhana">Garbhadhana</a> (pregnancy), <a href="/wiki/Pumsavana" title="Pumsavana">Pumsavana</a> (rite before the fetus begins moving and kicking in womb), <a href="/wiki/Simantonnayana" title="Simantonnayana">Simantonnayana</a> (parting of pregnant woman's hair, baby shower), <i>Jatakarman</i> (rite celebrating the new born baby), <i>Namakarana</i> (naming the child), <i>Nishkramana</i> (baby's first outing from home into the world), <i>Annaprashana</i> (baby's first feeding of solid food), <i>Chudakarana</i> (baby's first haircut, tonsure), <i>Karnavedha</i> (ear piercing), <i>Vidyarambha</i> (baby's start with knowledge), <a href="/wiki/Upanayana" title="Upanayana">Upanayana</a> (entry into a school rite),<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-380"><a href="#cite_note-380">[335]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-381"><a href="#cite_note-381">[336]</a></sup> <i>Keshanta</i> and <i>Ritusuddhi</i> (first shave for boys, menarche for girls), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Samavartana" title="Samavartana">Samavartana</a> (graduation ceremony), Vivaha (wedding), <i>Vratas</i> (fasting, spiritual studies) and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Antyeshti" title="Antyeshti">Antyeshti</a> (cremation for an adult, burial for a child).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-382"><a href="#cite_note-382">[337]</a></sup> In contemporary times, there is regional variation among Hindus as to which of these <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sa%E1%B9%83sk%C4%81ra" title="Saṃskāra">sanskaras</a> are observed; in some cases, additional regional rites of passage such as <i><a href="/wiki/%C5%9Ar%C4%81ddha" title="Śrāddha">Śrāddha</a></i> (ritual of feeding people after cremation) are practiced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-pvkanesamsk_377-2"><a href="#cite_note-pvkanesamsk-377">[332]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden1996146–148_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeitzmanWorden1996146–148-383">[338]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Bhakti_.28worship.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Bhakti_(worship)">Bhakti (worship)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Bhakti" title="Bhakti">Bhakti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">Japa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mantra" title="Mantra">Mantra</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Bhajan" title="Bhajan">Bhajan</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:292px;max-width:292px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:184px;max-width:184px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:136px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vishu-kani_1.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="2736" data-file-width="3648" decoding="async" height="137" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/182px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/273px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Vishu-kani_1.JPG/364px-Vishu-kani_1.JPG 2x" width="182"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:104px;max-width:104px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:136px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="800" data-file-width="600" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/102px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/153px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg/204px-Kumuthavalli_AvatharaAthalam.jpg 2x" width="102"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow" style="display:flex"><div class="thumbcaption">A home shrine with offerings at a regional <a href="/wiki/Vishu" title="Vishu">Vishu</a> festival (left); a priest in a temple (right).</div></div></div></div>
<p><i>Bhakti</i> refers to devotion, participation in and the love of a personal god or a representational god by a devotee.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-encyclopediabrit_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-encyclopediabrit-384">[web 16]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-karen_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-karen-385">[339]</a></sup> <i>Bhakti-marga</i> is considered in Hinduism to be one of many possible paths of spirituality and alternative means to moksha.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-386"><a href="#cite_note-386">[340]</a></sup> The other paths, left to the choice of a Hindu, are <i>Jnana-marga</i> (path of knowledge), <i>Karma-marga</i> (path of works), <i>Rāja-marga</i> (path of contemplation and meditation).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-johnmartin_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-johnmartin-387">[341]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-388"><a href="#cite_note-388">[342]</a></sup>
</p><p>Bhakti is practiced in a number of ways, ranging from reciting mantras, <a href="/wiki/Japa" title="Japa">japas</a> (incantations), to individual private prayers in one's home shrine,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-389"><a href="#cite_note-389">[343]</a></sup> or in a temple before a <a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">murti</a> or sacred image of a deity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-390"><a href="#cite_note-390">[344]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFowler199741–50_391-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFowler199741–50-391">[345]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temples</a> and domestic altars, are important elements of worship in contemporary theistic Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foulston2012p20_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-Foulston2012p20-392">[346]</a></sup> While many visit a temple on special occasions, most offer daily prayers at a domestic altar, typically a dedicated part of the home that includes sacred images of deities or gurus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Foulston2012p20_392-1"><a href="#cite_note-Foulston2012p20-392">[346]</a></sup>
</p><p>One form of daily worship is aarti, or "supplication," a ritual in which a flame is offered and "accompanied by a song of praise."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-:0-393">[347]</a></sup> Notable aartis include <a href="/wiki/Om_Jai_Jagdish_Hare" title="Om Jai Jagdish Hare">Om Jai Jagdish Hare</a>,a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindi_language" title="Hindi language">Hindi</a> prayer to <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Sukhakarta_Dukhaharta" title="Sukhakarta Dukhaharta">Sukhakarta Dukhaharta</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Marathi_language" title="Marathi language">Marathi</a>  to <a href="/wiki/Ganesha" title="Ganesha">Ganesha</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-394"><a href="#cite_note-394">[348]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-395"><a href="#cite_note-395">[349]</a></sup> Aarti can be used to make offerings to entities ranging from deities to "human exemplar[s]."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:0_393-1"><a href="#cite_note-:0-393">[347]</a></sup> For instance, Aarti is offered to <a href="/wiki/Hanuman" title="Hanuman">Hanuman</a>, a devotee of God, in many temples, including <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Balaji_Mandir_(disambiguation)" title="Balaji Mandir (disambiguation)">Balaji temples</a>, where the primary deity is an incarnation of <a href="/wiki/Venkateswara" title="Venkateswara">Vishnu</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-396"><a href="#cite_note-396">[350]</a></sup> In <a href="/wiki/Swaminarayan_Sampradaya" title="Swaminarayan Sampradaya">Swaminarayan</a> temples and home shrines, aarti is offered to <a href="/wiki/Swaminarayan" title="Swaminarayan">Swaminarayan</a>, considered by followers to be supreme God.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-397"><a href="#cite_note-397">[351]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other personal and community practices include puja as well as aarti,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002a51_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002a51-398">[352]</a></sup> kirtan, or bhajan, where devotional verses and hymns are read or poems are sung by a group of devotees.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-399"><a href="#cite_note-399">[web 17]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-400"><a href="#cite_note-400">[353]</a></sup> While the choice of the deity is at the discretion of the Hindu, the most observed traditions of Hindu devotion include Vaishnavism, Shaivism, and Shaktism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-401"><a href="#cite_note-401">[354]</a></sup> A Hindu may worship multiple deities, all as henotheistic manifestations of the same ultimate reality, cosmic spirit and absolute spiritual concept called Brahman.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrentiss2014_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrentiss2014-402">[355]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200072–75_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200072–75-403">[356]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-avatars_273-1"><a href="#cite_note-avatars-273">[236]</a></sup>
Bhakti-marga, states Pechelis, is more than ritual devotionalism, it includes practices and spiritual activities aimed at refining one's state of mind, knowing god, participating in god, and internalizing god.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPrentiss201422–29_404-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPrentiss201422–29-404">[357]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-405"><a href="#cite_note-405">[358]</a></sup> While bhakti practices are popular and easily observable aspect of Hinduism, not all Hindus practice bhakti, or believe in god-with-attributes (<i>saguna Brahman</i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-406"><a href="#cite_note-406">[359]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-407"><a href="#cite_note-407">[360]</a></sup> Concurrent Hindu practices include a belief in god-without-attributes, and god within oneself.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-408"><a href="#cite_note-408">[361]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[362]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Festivals">Festivals</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hindu_festivals" title="List of Hindu festivals">List of Hindu festivals</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Deepawali-festival.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="300" data-file-width="416" decoding="async" height="159" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Deepawali-festival.jpg/220px-Deepawali-festival.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5e/Deepawali-festival.jpg/330px-Deepawali-festival.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/5/5e/Deepawali-festival.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Deepawali-festival.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The festival of lights, <a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a>, is celebrated by Hindus all over the world.</div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="880" data-file-width="716" decoding="async" height="270" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg/220px-Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg/330px-Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a4/Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg/440px-Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hindus_in_Ghana_celebrating_Ganesh_Chaturti.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Ghana" title="Hinduism in Ghana">Hindus in Ghana</a> celebrating <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ganesh_Chaturti" title="Ganesh Chaturti">Ganesh Chaturti</a></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah,_United_States_2013.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1462" data-file-width="2200" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah%2C_United_States_2013.jpg/220px-Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah%2C_United_States_2013.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah%2C_United_States_2013.jpg/330px-Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah%2C_United_States_2013.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6a/Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah%2C_United_States_2013.jpg/440px-Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah%2C_United_States_2013.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Holi_Festival_of_Colors_Utah,_United_States_2013.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Holi" title="Holi">Holi</a> celebrated at the <a href="/wiki/Sri_Sri_Radha_Krishna_Temple_(Spanish_Fork)" title="Sri Sri Radha Krishna Temple (Spanish Fork)">Sri Sri Radha Krishna Temple</a> in <a href="/wiki/Utah" title="Utah">Utah</a>, <a href="/wiki/United_States" title="United States">United States</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Hindu festivals (Sanskrit: <i>Utsava</i>; literally: "to lift higher") are ceremonies that weave individual and social life to dharma.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandrarobinson_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-sandrarobinson-410">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yustf_411-0"><a href="#cite_note-yustf-411">[364]</a></sup> Hinduism has many festivals throughout the year, where the dates are set by the lunisolar <a href="/wiki/Hindu_calendar" title="Hindu calendar">Hindu calendar</a>, many coinciding with either the full moon (<i>Holi</i>) or the new moon (<i>Diwali</i>), often with seasonal changes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-denisecushf_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-denisecushf-412">[365]</a></sup> Some festivals are found only regionally and they celebrate local traditions, while a few such as <i>Holi</i> and <i>Diwali</i> are pan-Hindu.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-denisecushf_412-1"><a href="#cite_note-denisecushf-412">[365]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-413"><a href="#cite_note-413">[366]</a></sup>
The festivals typically celebrate events from Hinduism, connoting spiritual themes and celebrating aspects of human relationships such as the Sister-Brother bond over the <i>Raksha Bandhan</i> (or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhau-beej" title="Bhau-beej">Bhai Dooj</a>) festival.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-yustf_411-1"><a href="#cite_note-yustf-411">[364]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-414"><a href="#cite_note-414">[367]</a></sup> The same festival sometimes marks different stories depending on the Hindu denomination, and the celebrations incorporate regional themes, traditional agriculture, local arts, family get togethers, <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">Puja</a> rituals and feasts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-sandrarobinson_410-1"><a href="#cite_note-sandrarobinson-410">[363]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-415"><a href="#cite_note-415">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some major regional or pan-Hindu festivals include:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r998391716">.mw-parser-output .div-col{margin-top:0.3em;column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .div-col-small{font-size:90%}.mw-parser-output .div-col-rules{column-rule:1px solid #aaa}.mw-parser-output .div-col dl,.mw-parser-output .div-col ol,.mw-parser-output .div-col ul{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .div-col li,.mw-parser-output .div-col dd{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}</style><div class="div-col" style="column-width: 18em;">
<ul><li><a href="/wiki/Makar_Sankranti" title="Makar Sankranti">Makar Sankranti</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Pongal_(festival)" title="Pongal (festival)">Pongal</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Thaipusam" title="Thaipusam">Thaipusam</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vasant_Panchami" title="Vasant Panchami">Vasant Panchami</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Maha_Shivaratri" title="Maha Shivaratri">Maha Shivaratri</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Shigmo" title="Shigmo">Shigmo</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Holi" title="Holi">Holi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gudi_Padwa" title="Gudi Padwa">Gudi Padwa</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ugadi" title="Ugadi">Ugadi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Vishu" title="Vishu">Vishu</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ram_Navami" title="Ram Navami">Ram Navami</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Kartik_Purnima" title="Kartik Purnima">Kartik Purnima</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Raksha_Bandhan" title="Raksha Bandhan">Raksha Bandhan</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Krishna_Janmastami" title="Krishna Janmastami">Krishna Janmastami</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Gowri_Habba" title="Gowri Habba">Gowri Habba</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Ganesh_Chaturthi" title="Ganesh Chaturthi">Ganesh Chaturthi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Onam" title="Onam">Onam</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Navaratri" title="Navaratri">Navaratri</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Dussehra" title="Dussehra">Dussehra</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Durga_Puja" title="Durga Puja">Durga Puja</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Diwali" title="Diwali">Diwali</a> or <a href="/wiki/Tihar_(festival)" title="Tihar (festival)">Tihar</a> or <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Deepawali" title="Deepawali">Deepawali</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Chhath" title="Chhath">Chhath</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ashadhi_Ekadashi" title="Ashadhi Ekadashi">Ashadhi Ekadashi</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Bonalu" title="Bonalu">Bonalu</a></li>
<li><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rath_Yatra" title="Rath Yatra">Rath Yatra</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Dashain" title="Dashain">Dashain</a></li>
<li><a href="/wiki/Karva_Chauth" title="Karva Chauth">Karva Chauth</a></li></ul>
</div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Pilgrimage">Pilgrimage</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Tirtha_(Hinduism)" title="Tirtha (Hinduism)">Tirtha (Hinduism)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_pilgrimage_sites_in_India" title="Hindu pilgrimage sites in India">Tirtha locations</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Yatra" title="Yatra">Yatra</a></div>
<p>Many adherents undertake <a href="/wiki/Pilgrimage" title="Pilgrimage">pilgrimages</a>, which have historically been an important part of Hinduism and remain so today.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller2004204–05_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller2004204–05-416">[369]</a></sup> Pilgrimage sites are called <i><a href="/wiki/Tirtha_(Hinduism)" title="Tirtha (Hinduism)">Tirtha</a></i>, <i>Kshetra</i>, <i>Gopitha</i> or <i>Mahalaya</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002n698–699_417-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELochtefeld2002n698–699-417">[370]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJacobsen20134,_22,_27,_140–148,_157–158_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJacobsen20134,_22,_27,_140–148,_157–158-418">[371]</a></sup> The process or journey associated with <i>Tirtha</i> is called <i>Tirtha-yatra</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19832_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19832-419">[372]</a></sup> According to the Hindu text <i><a href="/wiki/Skanda_Purana" title="Skanda Purana">Skanda Purana</a></i>, Tirtha are of three kinds: Jangam Tirtha is to a place movable of a <a href="/wiki/Sadhu" title="Sadhu">sadhu</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Rishi" title="Rishi">rishi</a>, a <a href="/wiki/Guru" title="Guru">guru</a>; Sthawar Tirtha is to a place immovable, like Benaras, Haridwar, Mount Kailash, holy rivers; while Manas Tirtha is to a place of mind of truth, charity, patience, compassion, soft speech, Self.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[373]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-421"><a href="#cite_note-421">[374]</a></sup> <i>Tīrtha-yatra</i> is, states Knut A. Jacobsen, anything that has a salvific value to a Hindu, and includes pilgrimage sites such as mountains or forests or seashore or rivers or ponds, as well as virtues, actions, studies or state of mind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJacobsen2013157–158_422-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJacobsen2013157–158-422">[375]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004288–289_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004288–289-423">[376]</a></sup>
</p><p>Pilgrimage sites of Hinduism are mentioned in the epic Mahabharata and the <a href="/wiki/Puranas" title="Puranas">Puranas</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953561_424-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953561-424">[377]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck20127–9_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck20127–9-425">[378]</a></sup> Most Puranas include large sections on <i>Tirtha Mahatmya</i> along with tourist guides,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[379]</a></sup> which describe sacred sites and places to visit.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953559–560_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953559–560-427">[380]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolmBowker200168_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolmBowker200168-428">[381]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTERocher1986[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_October_2020]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(October_2020)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;_429-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTERocher1986[[Category:Wikipedia_articles_needing_page_number_citations_from_October_2020]]&lt;sup_class="noprint_Inline-Template_"_style="white-space:nowrap;"&gt;&amp;#91;&lt;i&gt;[[Wikipedia:Citing_sources|&lt;span_title="This_citation_requires_a_reference_to_the_specific_page_or_range_of_pages_in_which_the_material_appears.&amp;#32;(October_2020)"&gt;page&amp;nbsp;needed&lt;/span&gt;]]&lt;/i&gt;&amp;#93;&lt;/sup&gt;-429'>[382]</a></sup> In these texts, <a href="/wiki/Varanasi" title="Varanasi">Varanasi</a> (Benares, Kashi), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Rameshwaram" title="Rameshwaram">Rameshwaram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kanchipuram" title="Kanchipuram">Kanchipuram</a>, <a href="/wiki/Dwarka" title="Dwarka">Dwarka</a>, <a href="/wiki/Puri" title="Puri">Puri</a>, <a href="/wiki/Haridwar" title="Haridwar">Haridwar</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sri_Rangam" title="Sri Rangam">Sri Rangam</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vrindavan" title="Vrindavan">Vrindavan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ayodhya" title="Ayodhya">Ayodhya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Tirupati" title="Tirupati">Tirupati</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mayapur" title="Mayapur">Mayapur</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nathdwara" title="Nathdwara">Nathdwara</a>, twelve <a href="/wiki/Jyotirlinga" title="Jyotirlinga">Jyotirlinga</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shakti_Peetha" title="Shakti Peetha">Shakti Peetha</a> have been mentioned as particularly holy sites, along with geographies where major rivers meet (<i>sangam</i>) or join the sea.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953553–556,_560–561_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953553–556,_560–561-430">[383]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck20127–9_425-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck20127–9-425">[378]</a></sup> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kumbhamela" title="Kumbhamela">Kumbhamela</a> is another major pilgrimage on the eve of the solar festival <a href="/wiki/Makar_Sankranti" title="Makar Sankranti">Makar Sankranti</a>. This pilgrimage rotates at a gap of three years among four sites:  <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Prayag_Raj" title="Prayag Raj">Prayag Raj</a> at the confluence of the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a> and <a href="/wiki/Yamuna" title="Yamuna">Yamuna</a> rivers, <a href="/wiki/Haridwar" title="Haridwar">Haridwar</a> near source of the <a href="/wiki/Ganges" title="Ganges">Ganges</a>, <a href="/wiki/Ujjain" title="Ujjain">Ujjain</a> on the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Shipra" title="Shipra">Shipra</a> river and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nasik" title="Nasik">Nasik</a> on the bank of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Godavari" title="Godavari">Godavari</a> river.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck2013152–154_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck2013152–154-431">[384]</a></sup> This is one of world's largest mass pilgrimage, with an estimated 40 to 100 million people attending the event.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck2013152–154_431-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck2013152–154-431">[384]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2010553_note_55_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2010553_note_55-432">[385]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-433"><a href="#cite_note-433">[web 18]</a></sup> At this event, they say a prayer to the sun and bathe in the river,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck2013152–154_431-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck2013152–154-431">[384]</a></sup> a tradition attributed to <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDalal2010chapter_Kumbh_Mela_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDalal2010chapter_Kumbh_Mela-434">[386]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2388" data-file-width="2968" decoding="async" height="177" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg/220px-Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg/330px-Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg/440px-Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Kedar_Ghat_in_Varanasi.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Kedar Ghat, a bathing place for pilgrims on the Ganges at Varanasi</div></div></div>
<p>Some pilgrimages are part of a <i>Vrata</i> (vow), which a Hindu may make for a number of reasons.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck20129–11_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck20129–11-435">[387]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19836_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19836-436">[388]</a></sup> It may mark a special occasion, such as the birth of a baby, or as part of a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rite of passage</a> such as a baby's first haircut, or after healing from a sickness.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck20129_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck20129-437">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-438"><a href="#cite_note-438">[390]</a></sup> It may, states Eck, also be the result of prayers answered.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck20129_437-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck20129-437">[389]</a></sup> An alternative reason for Tirtha, for some Hindus, is to respect wishes or in memory of a beloved person after his or her death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck20129_437-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck20129-437">[389]</a></sup> This may include dispersing their cremation ashes in a Tirtha region in a stream, river or sea to honor the wishes of the dead. The journey to a Tirtha, assert some Hindu texts, helps one overcome the sorrow of the loss.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEck20129_437-3"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEck20129-437">[389]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[note 31]</a></sup>
</p><p>Other reasons for a Tirtha in Hinduism is to rejuvenate or gain spiritual merit by traveling to famed temples or bathe in rivers such as the Ganges.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19833–5_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19833–5-442">[393]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-443"><a href="#cite_note-443">[394]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHolmBowker200169–77_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHolmBowker200169–77-444">[395]</a></sup> Tirtha has been one of the recommended means of addressing remorse and to perform penance, for unintentional errors and intentional sins, in the Hindu tradition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELingat197398–99_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELingat197398–99-445">[396]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19834_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBhardwaj19834-446">[397]</a></sup> The proper procedure for a pilgrimage is widely discussed in Hindu texts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953573_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953573-447">[398]</a></sup> The most accepted view is that the greatest austerity comes from traveling on foot, or part of the journey is on foot, and that the use of a conveyance is only acceptable if the pilgrimage is otherwise impossible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKane1953576–577_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKane1953576–577-448">[399]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Culture">Culture</span></h2>
<p>The term "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_culture" title="Hindu culture">Hindu culture</a>" refers to mean aspects of culture that pertain to the religion, such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Festivals" title="Festivals">festivals</a> and dress codes followed by the <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">Hindus</a> which is mainly can be inspired from the <a href="/wiki/Culture_of_India" title="Culture of India">culture of India</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Culture_of_Southeast_Asia" title="Culture of Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>. Though there has been a mixture of different culture in Hinduism and has also influenced the cultures of many nations, mainly of the part of <a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">Greater India</a>.
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Architecture">Architecture</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1066933788">.mw-parser-output .excerpt-hat .mw-editsection-like{font-style:normal}</style><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Hindu_architecture" title="Hindu architecture">Hindu architecture</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hindu_architecture&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple,_Nagara_architecture,_Sunak,_Gujarat.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="420" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple%2C_Nagara_architecture%2C_Sunak%2C_Gujarat.jpg/280px-10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple%2C_Nagara_architecture%2C_Sunak%2C_Gujarat.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple%2C_Nagara_architecture%2C_Sunak%2C_Gujarat.jpg/420px-10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple%2C_Nagara_architecture%2C_Sunak%2C_Gujarat.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple%2C_Nagara_architecture%2C_Sunak%2C_Gujarat.jpg/560px-10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple%2C_Nagara_architecture%2C_Sunak%2C_Gujarat.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:10th_century_Nilakantha_Mahadeva_Hindu_temple,_Nagara_architecture,_Sunak,_Gujarat.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The architecture of a Hindu temple in Sunak, Gujarat.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Hindu_architecture" title="Hindu architecture">Hindu architecture</a> is the traditional system of Indian architecture for structures such as temples, monasteries, statues, homes, market places, gardens and town planning as described in <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">Hindu texts</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAcharya1927xviii-xx_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAcharya1927xviii-xx-449">[400]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_architecture_Sinha_1998_pp._27–41_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_architecture_Sinha_1998_pp._27–41-450">[401]</a></sup> The architectural guidelines survive in Sanskrit manuscripts and in some cases also in other regional languages. These texts include the <a href="/wiki/Vastu_shastra" title="Vastu shastra">Vastu shastras</a>, <a href="/wiki/Shilpa_Shastras" title="Shilpa Shastras">Shilpa Shastras</a>, the <i>Brihat Samhita</i>, architectural portions of the Puranas and the Agamas, and regional texts such as the <a href="/wiki/Manasara" title="Manasara">Manasara</a> among others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAcharya1927xviii-xx,_Appendix_I_lists_hundreds_of_Hindu_architectural_texts_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAcharya1927xviii-xx,_Appendix_I_lists_hundreds_of_Hindu_architectural_texts-451">[402]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShukla1993_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShukla1993-452">[403]</a></sup>
</p><p>By far the most important, characteristic and numerous surviving examples of Hindu architecture are <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temples</a>, with an <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple_architecture" title="Hindu temple architecture">architectural tradition</a> that has left surviving examples in stone, brick, and <a href="/wiki/Indian_rock-cut_architecture" title="Indian rock-cut architecture">rock-cut architecture</a> dating back to the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>. These architectures had influence of Ancient Persian and <a href="/wiki/Hellenistic_influence_on_Indian_art" title="Hellenistic influence on Indian art">Hellenistic</a> architecture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-453"><a href="#cite_note-453">[404]</a></sup> Far fewer secular Hindu architecture have survived into the modern era, such as palaces, homes and cities. Ruins and archaeological studies provide a view of early secular architecture in India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_architecture_Murthy1987_454-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_architecture_Murthy1987-454">[405]</a></sup>
</p>
Studies on Indian palaces and civic architectural history have largely focussed on the Mughal and Indo-Islamic architecture particularly of the northern and western India given their relative abundance. In other regions of India, particularly the South, Hindu architecture continued to thrive through the 16th-century, such as those exemplified by the temples, ruined cities and secular spaces of the Vijayanagara Empire and the Nayakas.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_architecture_Branfoot_2008_pp._171–194_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_architecture_Branfoot_2008_pp._171–194-455">[406]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_architecture_harle331_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_architecture_harle331-456">[407]</a></sup> The secular architecture was never opposed to the religious in India, and it is the sacred architecture such as those found in the Hindu temples which were inspired by and adaptations of the secular ones. Further, states Harle, it is in the reliefs on temple walls, pillars, toranas and madapams where miniature version of the secular architecture can be found.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_architecture_Harle1994_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_architecture_Harle1994-457">[408]</a></sup></div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Art">Art</span></h3>
<div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Hindu_art" title="Hindu art">Hindu art</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hindu_art&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:222px;max-width:222px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Hindu art</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:216px;max-width:216px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:288px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:FourArmedVishnuPandyaDynasty8-9thCentury.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1634" data-file-width="1211" decoding="async" height="289" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/FourArmedVishnuPandyaDynasty8-9thCentury.jpg/214px-FourArmedVishnuPandyaDynasty8-9thCentury.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/FourArmedVishnuPandyaDynasty8-9thCentury.jpg/321px-FourArmedVishnuPandyaDynasty8-9thCentury.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b4/FourArmedVishnuPandyaDynasty8-9thCentury.jpg/428px-FourArmedVishnuPandyaDynasty8-9thCentury.jpg 2x" width="214"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center">Four-armed <a href="/wiki/Vishnu" title="Vishnu">Vishnu</a> seated in <i><a href="/wiki/Lalitasana" title="Lalitasana">lalitasana</a></i>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Pandya_Dynasty" title="Pandya Dynasty">Pandya Dynasty</a>, 8-9th century <span title="Common Era">CE</span></div></div></div></div></div>
<a href="/wiki/Hindu_art" title="Hindu art">Hindu art</a> encompasses the artistic traditions and styles culturally connected to Hinduism and have a long history of religious association with Hindu scriptures, rituals and worship.</div></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Calendar">Calendar</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Astronomical_basis_of_the_Hindu_calendar" title="Astronomical basis of the Hindu calendar">Astronomical basis of the Hindu calendar</a></div><div class="excerpt-block"><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1066933788" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable dablink excerpt-hat selfref" role="note">This section is an excerpt from <a href="/wiki/Hindu_calendar" title="Hindu calendar">Hindu calendar</a>.<span class="mw-editsection-like plainlinks"><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">[</span><a class="external text" href="https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Hindu_calendar&amp;action=edit">edit</a><span class="mw-editsection-bracket">]</span></span></div><div class="excerpt">
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1731" data-file-width="640" decoding="async" height="595" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg/220px-Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg/330px-Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/04/Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg/440px-Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Hindu_calendar_1871-72.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A page from the Hindu calendar 1871-72</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Hindu_calendar" title="Hindu calendar">Hindu calendar</a>, Panchanga (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskrit_language" title="Sanskrit language">Sanskrit</a>: <span lang="sa">पञ्चाङ्ग</span>) or Panjika is one of various <a href="/wiki/Lunisolar_calendar" title="Lunisolar calendar">lunisolar calendars</a> that are traditionally used in the <a href="/wiki/Indian_subcontinent" title="Indian subcontinent">Indian subcontinent</a> and <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a>, with further regional variations for social and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindu</a> religious purposes. They adopt a similar underlying concept for timekeeping based on <a href="/wiki/Sidereal_year" title="Sidereal year">sidereal year</a> for solar cycle and adjustment of lunar cycles in every three years, but differ in their relative emphasis to moon cycle or the sun cycle and the names of months and when they consider the New Year to start.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_calendar_richmond80_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_calendar_richmond80-458">[409]</a></sup> Of the various regional calendars, the most studied and known Hindu calendars are the <a href="/wiki/Shaka_era" title="Shaka era">Shalivahana Shaka</a>(Based on the <a href="/wiki/Shalivahana" title="Shalivahana">King Shalivahana</a>, also the <a href="/wiki/Indian_national_calendar" title="Indian national calendar">Indian national calendar</a>) found in the <a href="/wiki/Deccan_Plateau" title="Deccan Plateau">Deccan region</a> of Southern India and the <a href="/wiki/Vikram_Samvat" title="Vikram Samvat">Vikram Samvat</a> (Bikrami) found in Nepal and the North and Central regions of <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> – both of which emphasize the lunar cycle. Their new year starts in spring. In regions such as Tamil Nadu and Kerala, the solar cycle is emphasized and this is called the <a href="/wiki/Tamil_calendar" title="Tamil calendar">Tamil calendar</a> (Though Tamil Calendar uses month names like in Hindu Calendar) and <a href="/wiki/Malayalam_calendar" title="Malayalam calendar">Malayalam calendar</a> and these have origins in the second half of the 1st millennium CE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_calendar_richmond80_458-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_calendar_richmond80-458">[409]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_calendar_Fuller2004p109_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_calendar_Fuller2004p109-459">[410]</a></sup> A Hindu calendar is sometimes referred to as <a href="/wiki/Panchangam" title="Panchangam">Panchangam</a> (पञ्चाङ्ग), which is known also known as <a href="/wiki/Panjika" title="Panjika">Panjika</a> in Eastern India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-460"><a href="#cite_note-460">[411]</a></sup>
</p><p>The ancient Hindu calendar conceptual design is also found in the <a href="/wiki/Hebrew_calendar" title="Hebrew calendar">Hebrew calendar</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Chinese_calendar" title="Chinese calendar">Chinese calendar</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Babylonian_calendar" title="Babylonian calendar">Babylonian calendar</a>, but different from the Gregorian calendar.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_calendar_nesbittbc_461-0"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_calendar_nesbittbc-461">[412]</a></sup> Unlike the Gregorian calendar which adds additional days to the month to adjust for the mismatch between twelve lunar cycles (354 lunar days)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-462"><a href="#cite_note-462">[413]</a></sup> and nearly 365 solar days, the Hindu calendar maintains the integrity of the lunar month, but inserts an extra full month by complex rules, once every 32–33 months, to ensure that the festivals and crop-related rituals fall in the appropriate season.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_calendar_nesbittbc_461-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_calendar_nesbittbc-461">[412]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Hindu_calendar_Fuller2004p109_459-1"><a href="#cite_note-Hindu_calendar_Fuller2004p109-459">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Hindu calendars have been in use in the Indian subcontinent since Vedic times, and remain in use by the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindus</a> all over the world, particularly to set Hindu festival dates. Early Buddhist communities of India adopted the ancient Vedic calendar, later Vikrami calendar and then local <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_calendar" title="Buddhist calendar">Buddhist calendars</a>. Buddhist festivals continue to be scheduled according to a lunar system.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-463"><a href="#cite_note-463">[414]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Buddhist_calendar" title="Buddhist calendar">Buddhist calendar</a> and the traditional lunisolar calendars of <a href="/wiki/Cambodia" title="Cambodia">Cambodia</a>, <a href="/wiki/Laos" title="Laos">Laos</a>, <a href="/wiki/Myanmar" title="Myanmar">Myanmar</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sri_Lanka" title="Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a> and <a href="/wiki/Thailand" title="Thailand">Thailand</a> are also based on an older version of the Hindu calendar. Similarly, the ancient <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Jain" title="Jain">Jain</a> traditions have followed the same lunisolar system as the Hindu calendar for festivals, texts and inscriptions. However, the Buddhist and Jain timekeeping systems have attempted to use the Buddha and the Mahavira's lifetimes as their reference points.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-464"><a href="#cite_note-464">[415]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-465"><a href="#cite_note-465">[416]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-466"><a href="#cite_note-466">[417]</a></sup>
</p>
The Hindu calendar is also important to the practice of Hindu astrology and zodiac system as well as observing special appearance days of the <a href="/wiki/Krishna" title="Krishna">Lord</a> and fasting days such as <a href="/wiki/Ekadashi" title="Ekadashi">Ekadashi</a>.</div></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Person_and_society">Person and society</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Varnas">Varnas</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">Varna (Hinduism)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:12BCM11.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="628" data-file-width="945" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/12BCM11.jpg/220px-12BCM11.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/12BCM11.jpg/330px-12BCM11.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/df/12BCM11.jpg/440px-12BCM11.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:12BCM11.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Priests performing <i>Kalyanam</i> (marriage) of the holy deities at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhadrachalam_Temple" title="Bhadrachalam Temple">Bhadrachalam Temple</a>, in <a href="/wiki/Telangana" title="Telangana">Telangana</a>. It is one of the temples in India, where <i>Kalyanam</i> is done everyday throughout the year.</div></div></div>
<p>Hindu society has been categorised into four classes, called <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)"><i>varṇas</i></a>. They are the <i><a href="/wiki/Brahmin" title="Brahmin">Brahmins</a></i>: <a href="/wiki/Vedas" title="Vedas">Vedic</a> teachers and priests; the <i><a href="/wiki/Kshatriya" title="Kshatriya">Kshatriyas</a></i>: warriors and kings; the <i><a href="/wiki/Vaishya" title="Vaishya">Vaishyas</a></i>: farmers and merchants; and the <i><a href="/wiki/Shudra" title="Shudra">Shudras</a></i>: servants and labourers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2000132–180_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2000132–180-467">[418]</a></sup>
The <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gītā</a></i> links the varṇa to an individual's duty (<i>svadharma</i>), inborn nature (<i>svabhāva</i>), and natural tendencies (<i><a href="/wiki/Gu%E1%B9%87a" title="Guṇa">guṇa</a></i>).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHalbfass1995264_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHalbfass1995264-468">[419]</a></sup> The <i><a href="/wiki/Manusmriti" title="Manusmriti">Manusmriti</a></i> categorises the different <a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">castes</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-469"><a href="#cite_note-469">[web 19]</a></sup>
Some mobility and flexibility within the <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varṇas</a> challenge allegations of social discrimination in the <a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">caste system</a>, as has been pointed out by several sociologists,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Silverberg_Paper_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-Silverberg_Paper-470">[420]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESmelserLipset2005_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESmelserLipset2005-471">[421]</a></sup> although some other scholars disagree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-472"><a href="#cite_note-472">[422]</a></sup> Scholars debate whether the so-called <i><a href="/wiki/Caste_system_in_India" title="Caste system in India">caste system</a></i> is part of Hinduism sanctioned by the scriptures or social custom.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004188–197_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004188–197-473">[423]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-474"><a href="#cite_note-474">[web 20]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[note 32]</a></sup> And various contemporary scholars have argued that the caste system was constructed by the <a href="/wiki/British_Raj" title="British Raj">British colonial regime</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-477"><a href="#cite_note-477">[424]</a></sup>
</p><p>A <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">renunciant</a> man of knowledge is usually called <i>Varṇatita</i> or "beyond all varṇas" in <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedantic</a> works. The bhiksu is advised to not bother about the caste of the family from which he begs his food. Scholars like <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Sankara</a> affirm that not only is <a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a> beyond all <a href="/wiki/Varna_(Hinduism)" title="Varna (Hinduism)">varṇas</a>, the man who is identified with Him also transcends the distinctions and limitations of caste.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-478"><a href="#cite_note-478">[425]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Yoga">Yoga</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Bangalore.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="822" data-file-width="832" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/220px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/330px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Shiva_Bangalore.jpg/440px-Shiva_Bangalore.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shiva_Bangalore.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A statue of Lord <a href="/wiki/Shiva" title="Shiva">Shiva</a> in yogic meditation.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a></div>
<p>In whatever way a Hindu defines the goal of life, there are several methods (yogas) that <a href="/wiki/Rishi" title="Rishi">sages</a> have taught for reaching that goal. <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a> is a Hindu discipline which trains the body, mind, and consciousness for health, <a href="/wiki/%C4%80tman_(Hinduism)" title="Ātman (Hinduism)">tranquility</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Enlightenment_(spiritual)" title="Enlightenment (spiritual)">spiritual insight</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-479"><a href="#cite_note-479">[426]</a></sup> Texts dedicated to <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">yoga</a> include the <i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras" title="Yoga Sutras">Yoga Sutras</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Hatha_Yoga_Pradipika" title="Hatha Yoga Pradipika">Hatha Yoga Pradipika</a></i>, the <i><a href="/wiki/Bhagavad_Gita" title="Bhagavad Gita">Bhagavad Gita</a></i> and, as their philosophical and historical basis, the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a>. <a href="/wiki/Yoga" title="Yoga">Yoga</a> is means, and the four major <i>marga</i> (paths) of Hinduism are: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Bhakti_Yoga" title="Bhakti Yoga">Bhakti Yoga</a> (the path of love and devotion), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Karma_Yoga" title="Karma Yoga">Karma Yoga</a> (the path of right action), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/R%C4%81ja_Yoga" title="Rāja Yoga">Rāja Yoga</a> (the path of meditation), and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/J%C3%B1%C4%81na_Yoga" title="Jñāna Yoga">Jñāna Yoga</a> (the path of wisdom)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bhaskaressentgeneral_480-0"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaressentgeneral-480">[427]</a></sup> An individual may prefer one or some yogas over others, according to his or her inclination and understanding. Practice of one yoga does not exclude others. The modern practice of <a href="/wiki/Yoga_as_exercise" title="Yoga as exercise">yoga as exercise</a> (traditionally <a href="/wiki/Hatha_yoga" title="Hatha yoga">Hatha yoga</a>) has a contested relationship with Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJain2015130–157_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJain2015130–157-481">[428]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Symbolism">Symbolism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png/220px-Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png/330px-Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/15/Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png/440px-Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Basic_Hindu_Symbols.png" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Basic Hindu symbols: Shatkona, Padma, and Swastika.</div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism has a developed system of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_iconography" title="Hindu iconography">symbolism and iconography</a> to represent the sacred in art, architecture, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_texts" title="Hindu texts">literature</a> and worship. These symbols gain their meaning from the scriptures or cultural traditions. The syllable <i><a href="/wiki/Om" title="Om">Om</a></i> (which represents the <i><a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a></i> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Atman_(Hinduism)" title="Atman (Hinduism)">Atman</a>) has grown to represent Hinduism itself, while other markings such as the <a href="/wiki/Swastika#Hinduism" title="Swastika">Swastika</a> sign represent auspiciousness,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDoniger20001041_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDoniger20001041-482">[429]</a></sup> and <i><a href="/wiki/Tilaka" title="Tilaka">Tilaka</a></i> (literally, seed) on forehead – considered to be the location of <a href="/wiki/Third_eye" title="Third eye">spiritual third eye</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-483"><a href="#cite_note-483">[430]</a></sup> marks ceremonious welcome, blessing or one's participation in a <a href="/wiki/Puja_(Hinduism)" title="Puja (Hinduism)">ritual or rite of passage</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-484"><a href="#cite_note-484">[431]</a></sup> Elaborate <i>Tilaka</i> with lines may also identify a devotee of a particular denomination. Flowers, birds, animals, instruments, symmetric <a href="/wiki/Mandala" title="Mandala">mandala</a> drawings, objects, idols are all part of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_iconography" title="Hindu iconography">symbolic iconography</a> in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-485"><a href="#cite_note-485">[432]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-486"><a href="#cite_note-486">[433]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:left;"></div>
<h3><span id="Ahi.E1.B9.83s.C4.81_and_food_customs"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Ahiṃsā_and_food_customs">Ahiṃsā and food customs</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">Ahimsa</a>, <a href="/wiki/Diet_in_Hinduism" title="Diet in Hinduism">Diet in Hinduism</a>, <a href="/wiki/Sattvic_diet" title="Sattvic diet">Sattvic diet</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mitahara" title="Mitahara">Mitahara</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Jhatka" title="Jhatka">Jhatka</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:192px;max-width:192px"><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:190px;max-width:190px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:141px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gosala_in_Guntur,_India.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1704" data-file-width="2272" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/188px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/282px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d6/Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg/376px-Gosala_in_Guntur%2C_India.jpg 2x" width="188"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">A goshala or cow shelter at <a href="/wiki/Guntur" title="Guntur">Guntur</a>.</div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:190px;max-width:190px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:125px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:%278%27_A_Thali,_a_traditional_style_of_serving_meal_in_India.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3456" data-file-width="5184" decoding="async" height="125" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/%278%27_A_Thali%2C_a_traditional_style_of_serving_meal_in_India.jpg/188px-%278%27_A_Thali%2C_a_traditional_style_of_serving_meal_in_India.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/%278%27_A_Thali%2C_a_traditional_style_of_serving_meal_in_India.jpg/282px-%278%27_A_Thali%2C_a_traditional_style_of_serving_meal_in_India.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7a/%278%27_A_Thali%2C_a_traditional_style_of_serving_meal_in_India.jpg/376px-%278%27_A_Thali%2C_a_traditional_style_of_serving_meal_in_India.jpg 2x" width="188"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption">A vegetarian <i><a href="/wiki/Thali" title="Thali">thali</a></i></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Hindus advocate the practice of <span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahiṃsā</a></i></span> (<a href="/wiki/Nonviolence" title="Nonviolence">nonviolence</a>) and respect for all life because divinity is believed to permeate all beings, including plants and non-human animals.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams1974_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMonier-Williams1974-487">[434]</a></sup> The term <i><span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">ahiṃsā</i></span></i> appears in the <a href="/wiki/Upanishads" title="Upanishads">Upanishads</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Radhakrishnan_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-Radhakrishnan-488">[435]</a></sup> the epic <a href="/wiki/Mahabharata" title="Mahabharata">Mahabharata</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-489"><a href="#cite_note-489">[436]</a></sup> and <span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn">ahiṃsā</i></span> is the first of the five <a href="/wiki/Yamas" title="Yamas">Yamas</a> (vows of self-restraint) in <a href="/wiki/Yoga_Sutras_of_Patanjali" title="Yoga Sutras of Patanjali">Patanjali's Yoga Sutras</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-490"><a href="#cite_note-490">[437]</a></sup>
</p><p>In accordance with <span title="International Alphabet of Sanskrit transliteration"><i lang="sa-Latn"><a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahiṃsā</a></i></span>, many Hindus embrace <a href="/wiki/Vegetarianism" title="Vegetarianism">vegetarianism</a> to respect higher forms of life. Estimates of strict <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lacto_vegetarian" title="Lacto vegetarian">lacto vegetarians</a> in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a> (includes adherents of all religions) who never eat any meat, fish or eggs vary between 20% and 42%, while others are either less strict vegetarians or non-vegetarians.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-veg_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-veg-491">[438]</a></sup> Those who eat meat seek <a href="/wiki/Jhatka" title="Jhatka">Jhatka</a> (quick death) method of meat production, and dislike <a href="/wiki/Halal" title="Halal">Halal</a> (slow bled death) method, believing that quick death method reduces suffering to the animal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-492"><a href="#cite_note-492">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-493"><a href="#cite_note-493">[440]</a></sup> The food habits vary with region, with Bengali Hindus and Hindus living in <a href="/wiki/Himalayas" title="Himalayas">Himalayan regions</a>, or river delta regions, regularly eating meat and fish.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-494"><a href="#cite_note-494">[441]</a></sup> Some avoid meat on specific festivals or occasions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-495"><a href="#cite_note-495">[442]</a></sup> Observant Hindus who do eat meat almost always abstain from beef. Hinduism specifically considers <a href="/wiki/Zebu" title="Zebu">Bos indicus</a> to be sacred.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-496"><a href="#cite_note-496">[443]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-497"><a href="#cite_note-497">[444]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-498"><a href="#cite_note-498">[445]</a></sup> The <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cow" title="Cow">cow</a> in Hindu society is traditionally identified as a caretaker and a maternal figure,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWalker1968257_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWalker1968257-499">[446]</a></sup> and Hindu society honours the cow as a symbol of unselfish giving,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERichman1988272_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERichman1988272-500">[447]</a></sup> selfless sacrifice, gentleness and tolerance.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ajai16P_pg62_501-0"><a href="#cite_note-ajai16P_pg62-501">[448]</a></sup>
There are many Hindu groups that have continued to abide by a strict <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vegetarian" title="Vegetarian">vegetarian</a> diet in modern times. Some adhere to a diet that is devoid of meat, eggs, and seafood.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-502"><a href="#cite_note-502">[449]</a></sup> Food affects body, mind and spirit in Hindu beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vasudha_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vasudha-503">[450]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Rosen_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-Rosen-504">[451]</a></sup> Hindu texts such as <a href="/wiki/Shandilya_Upanishad" title="Shandilya Upanishad">Śāṇḍilya Upanishad</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-KN_Aiyar_1914_pages_173-176_505-0"><a href="#cite_note-KN_Aiyar_1914_pages_173-176-505">[452]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Hatha_Yoga_Pradipika" title="Hatha Yoga Pradipika">Svātmārāma</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-svatmaram_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-svatmaram-506">[453]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[454]</a></sup> recommend <a href="/wiki/Mitahara" title="Mitahara">Mitahara</a> (eating in moderation) as one of the <a href="/wiki/Yamas" title="Yamas">Yamas</a> (virtuous Self restraints). The Bhagavad Gita links body and mind to food one consumes in verses 17.8 through 17.10.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ckc_508-0"><a href="#cite_note-ckc-508">[455]</a></sup>
