</p><p>Some Hindus such as those belonging to the <a href="/wiki/Shaktism" title="Shaktism">Shaktism</a> tradition,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-509"><a href="#cite_note-509">[456]</a></sup> and Hindus in regions such as <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a><sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200483"Chapter_4"_510-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200483"Chapter_4"-510'>[457]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-511"><a href="#cite_note-511">[458]</a></sup> practise <a href="/wiki/Animal_sacrifice_in_Hinduism" title="Animal sacrifice in Hinduism">animal sacrifice</a>.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller200483"Chapter_4"_510-1'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller200483"Chapter_4"-510'>[457]</a></sup> The sacrificed animal is eaten as ritual food.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-512"><a href="#cite_note-512">[459]</a></sup> In contrast, the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Vaishnava" title="Vaishnava">Vaishnava</a> Hindus abhor and vigorously oppose animal sacrifice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-513"><a href="#cite_note-513">[460]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101–102,_Quote:_&quot;Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point,_(,_,_,_)_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism's_central_tenet_of_non-violence._[...]_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation,_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism,_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes&quot;._514-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFuller2004101–102,_Quote:_&quot;Blood_sacrifice_was_a_clear_case_in_point,_(,_,_,_)_sacrifice_was_a_barbarity_inconsistent_with_Hinduism's_central_tenet_of_non-violence._[...]_Contemporary_opposition_to_animal_sacrifice_rests_on_an_old_foundation,_although_it_also_stems_from_the_very_widespread_influence_of_reformism,_whose_antipathy_to_ritual_killing_has_spread_well_beyond_the_self-consciously_nationalist_political_classes&quot;.-514">[461]</a></sup> The principle of non-violence to animals has been so thoroughly adopted in Hinduism that animal sacrifice is uncommon<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[462]</a></sup> and historically reduced to a vestigial marginal practice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-516"><a href="#cite_note-516">[463]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Institutions">Institutions</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Temple">Temple</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a>, <a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">Murti</a>, <a href="/wiki/Hindu_iconography" title="Hindu iconography">Hindu iconography</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Hindu_architecture" title="Hindu architecture">Hindu architecture</a></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">For list of temples, see <a href="/wiki/List_of_Hindu_temples" title="List of Hindu temples">List of Hindu temples</a>.</div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1096954695/mw-parser-output/.tmulti" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="thumb tmulti tright"><div class="thumbinner multiimageinner" style="width:592px;max-width:592px"><div class="trow"><div class="theader">Illustration of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temples</a> in Asia</div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:195px;max-width:195px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Vadakkunnathan_Temple_west_nada_DSC_0595.JPG"><img alt="" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="6000" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Vadakkunnathan_Temple_west_nada_DSC_0595.JPG/193px-Vadakkunnathan_Temple_west_nada_DSC_0595.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Vadakkunnathan_Temple_west_nada_DSC_0595.JPG/290px-Vadakkunnathan_Temple_west_nada_DSC_0595.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/Vadakkunnathan_Temple_west_nada_DSC_0595.JPG/386px-Vadakkunnathan_Temple_west_nada_DSC_0595.JPG 2x" width="193"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:195px;max-width:195px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Natarajartemple1.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3888" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Natarajartemple1.jpg/193px-Natarajartemple1.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Natarajartemple1.jpg/290px-Natarajartemple1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6f/Natarajartemple1.jpg/386px-Natarajartemple1.jpg 2x" width="193"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:195px;max-width:195px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:128px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Kolkatatemple.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1088" data-file-width="1632" decoding="async" height="129" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Kolkatatemple.jpg/193px-Kolkatatemple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Kolkatatemple.jpg/290px-Kolkatatemple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a1/Kolkatatemple.jpg/386px-Kolkatatemple.jpg 2x" width="193"/></a></div></div></div><div class="trow"><div class="tsingle" style="width:178px;max-width:178px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:117px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="3840" data-file-width="5760" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg/176px-Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg/264px-Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4f/Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg/352px-Besakih_Bali_Indonesia_Pura-Besakih-02.jpg 2x" width="176"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:158px;max-width:158px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:117px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:New_Delhi_Temple.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/New_Delhi_Temple.jpg/156px-New_Delhi_Temple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/New_Delhi_Temple.jpg/234px-New_Delhi_Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/New_Delhi_Temple.jpg/312px-New_Delhi_Temple.jpg 2x" width="156"/></a></div></div><div class="tsingle" style="width:250px;max-width:250px"><div class="thumbimage" style="height:117px;overflow:hidden"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Pashupatinath_temple_at_night_time.jpg"><img alt="" data-file-height="1908" data-file-width="4032" decoding="async" height="117" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Pashupatinath_temple_at_night_time.jpg/248px-Pashupatinath_temple_at_night_time.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Pashupatinath_temple_at_night_time.jpg/372px-Pashupatinath_temple_at_night_time.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Pashupatinath_temple_at_night_time.jpg/496px-Pashupatinath_temple_at_night_time.jpg 2x" width="248"/></a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>A <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">Hindu temple</a> is a house of god(s).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichell198861–65_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichell198861–65-517">[464]</a></sup> It is a space and structure designed to bring human beings and gods together, infused with symbolism to express the ideas and beliefs of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-518">[465]</a></sup> A temple incorporates all elements of Hindu cosmology, the highest spire or dome representing <a href="/wiki/Mount_Meru" title="Mount Meru">Mount Meru</a> – reminder of the abode of Brahma and the center of spiritual universe,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKramrisch1976a161–169_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKramrisch1976a161–169-519">[466]</a></sup> the carvings and iconography symbolically presenting <a href="/wiki/Dharma" title="Dharma">dharma</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kama" title="Kama">kama</a>, <a href="/wiki/Artha" title="Artha">artha</a>, <a href="/wiki/Moksha" title="Moksha">moksha</a> and <a href="/wiki/Karma" title="Karma">karma</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKramrisch1976b346–357,_423–424_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKramrisch1976b346–357,_423–424-520">[467]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007a268–277_521-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKlostermaier2007a268–277-521">[468]</a></sup> The layout, the motifs, the plan and the building process recite ancient rituals, geometric symbolisms, and reflect beliefs and values innate within various schools of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_518-1"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-518">[465]</a></sup> Hindu temples are spiritual destinations for many Hindus (not all), as well as landmarks for arts, annual festivals, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sanskara_(rite_of_passage)" title="Sanskara (rite of passage)">rite of passage</a> rituals, and community celebrations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-522"><a href="#cite_note-522">[469]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichell198858–65_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichell198858–65-523">[470]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hindu temples come in many styles, diverse locations, deploy different construction methods and are adapted to different deities and regional beliefs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-524"><a href="#cite_note-524">[471]</a></sup> Two major styles of Hindu temples include the <a href="/wiki/Gopuram" title="Gopuram">Gopuram</a> style found in south India, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Nagara_architecture" title="Nagara architecture">Nagara</a> style found in north India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[web 22]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[web 23]</a></sup> Other styles include cave, forest and mountain temples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[472]</a></sup> Yet, despite their differences, almost all Hindu temples share certain common architectural principles, core ideas, symbolism and themes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_518-2"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-518">[465]</a></sup>
Many temples feature one or more idols (<a href="/wiki/Murti" title="Murti">murtis</a>). The idol and Grabhgriya in the Brahma-pada (the center of the temple), under the main spire, serves as a focal point (<i>darsana</i>, a sight) in a Hindu temple.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKramrisch1976a8–9_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKramrisch1976a8–9-528">[473]</a></sup> In larger temples, the central space typically is surrounded by an ambulatory for the devotee to walk around and ritually circumambulate the <a href="/wiki/Purusha" title="Purusha">Purusa</a> (<a href="/wiki/Brahman" title="Brahman">Brahman</a>), the universal essence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-stellakvol1_518-3"><a href="#cite_note-stellakvol1-518">[465]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Asrama">Asrama</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Iraivan_Temple.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="4000" decoding="async" height="165" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Iraivan_Temple.jpg/220px-Iraivan_Temple.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Iraivan_Temple.jpg/330px-Iraivan_Temple.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/34/Iraivan_Temple.jpg/440px-Iraivan_Temple.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Iraivan_Temple.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Saiva_Siddhanta_Church" title="Saiva Siddhanta Church">Kauai Hindu monastery</a> in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Kauai_Island" title="Kauai Island">Kauai Island</a> in Hawaii is the only Hindu Monastery in the North American continent.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/%C4%80%C5%9Brama_(stage)" title="Āśrama (stage)">Āśrama (stage)</a></div>
<p>Traditionally the life of a Hindu is divided into four Āśramas (phases or life stages; another meaning includes monastery).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-529"><a href="#cite_note-529">[474]</a></sup> The four ashramas are: <a href="/wiki/Brahmacharya" title="Brahmacharya">Brahmacharya</a> (student), <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Grihastha" title="Grihastha">Grihastha</a> (householder), <a href="/wiki/V%C4%81naprastha" title="Vānaprastha">Vānaprastha</a> (retired) and <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a> (renunciation).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rks_530-0"><a href="#cite_note-rks-530">[475]</a></sup>
Brahmacharya represents the bachelor student stage of life. Grihastha refers to the individual's married life, with the duties of maintaining a household, raising a family, educating one's children, and leading a family-centred and a dharmic social life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rks_530-1"><a href="#cite_note-rks-530">[475]</a></sup> Grihastha stage starts with Hindu wedding, and has been considered the most important of all stages in sociological context, as Hindus in this stage not only pursued a virtuous life, they produced food and wealth that sustained people in other stages of life, as well as the offsprings that continued mankind.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWidgery1930_531-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWidgery1930-531">[476]</a></sup> Vanaprastha is the retirement stage, where a person hands over household responsibilities to the next generation, took an advisory role, and gradually withdrew from the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-alnu_532-0"><a href="#cite_note-alnu-532">[477]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-533"><a href="#cite_note-533">[478]</a></sup> The Sannyasa stage marks renunciation and a state of disinterest and detachment from material life, generally without any meaningful property or home (ascetic state), and focused on Moksha, peace and simple spiritual life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-534"><a href="#cite_note-534">[479]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110_535-0"><a href="#cite_note-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110-535">[480]</a></sup>
The Ashramas system has been one facet of the dharma concept in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWidgery1930_531-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWidgery1930-531">[476]</a></sup> Combined with four proper goals of human life (<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Purusartha" title="Purusartha">Purusartha</a>), the Ashramas system traditionally aimed at providing a Hindu with fulfilling life and spiritual liberation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWidgery1930_531-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWidgery1930-531">[476]</a></sup> While these stages are typically sequential, any person can enter Sannyasa (ascetic) stage and become an Ascetic at any time after the Brahmacharya stage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-536"><a href="#cite_note-536">[481]</a></sup> Sannyasa is not religiously mandatory in Hinduism, and elderly people are free to live with their families.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-537"><a href="#cite_note-537">[482]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Monasticism">Monasticism</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="461" data-file-width="691" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/220px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/330px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6b/Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg/440px-Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Indian_sadhu_performing_namaste.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A sadhu in <a href="/wiki/Madurai" title="Madurai">Madurai</a>, India.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sannyasa</a></div>
<p>Some Hindus choose to live a <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Monastic" title="Monastic">monastic</a> life (Sannyāsa) in pursuit of liberation (moksha) or another form of spiritual perfection.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ellinger70_30-1"><a href="#cite_note-ellinger70-30">[22]</a></sup> Monastics commit themselves to a simple and celibate life, detached from material pursuits, of meditation and spiritual contemplation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bhaskaranandaessential112_538-0"><a href="#cite_note-bhaskaranandaessential112-538">[483]</a></sup> A Hindu monk is called a <i><a href="/wiki/Sannyasa" title="Sannyasa">Sanyāsī</a></i>, <i>Sādhu</i>, or <i>Swāmi</i>. A female renunciate is called a <i>Sanyāsini</i>. Renunciates receive high respect in Hindu society because of their simple <a href="/wiki/Ahimsa" title="Ahimsa">ahiṃsā</a>-driven lifestyle and dedication to spiritual liberation (moksha) – believed to be the ultimate goal of life in Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110_535-1"><a href="#cite_note-DP_Bhawuk_2011_pages_93-110-535">[480]</a></sup> Some monastics live in monasteries, while others wander from place to place, depending on donated food and charity for their needs.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004316_539-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004316-539">[484]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="History">History</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/History_of_Hinduism" title="History of Hinduism">History of Hinduism</a></div>
<p>Hinduism's varied history<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003_27-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrodd2003-27">[20]</a></sup> overlaps or coincides with the development of religion in the Indian subcontinent since the <a href="/wiki/Iron_Age_in_India" title="Iron Age in India">Iron Age</a>, with some of its traditions tracing back to <a href="/wiki/Prehistoric_religion" title="Prehistoric religion">prehistoric religions</a> such as those of the Bronze Age <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Indus_Valley_civilisation" title="Indus Valley civilisation">Indus Valley civilisation</a>. It has thus been called the "<a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oldest_religion" title="Oldest religion">oldest religion</a>" in the world.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-541"><a href="#cite_note-541">[note 33]</a></sup> Scholars regard Hinduism as a synthesis<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELockard200750_542-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELockard200750-542">[486]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-6"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup> of various Indian cultures and traditions,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712_44-7"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHiltebeitel200712-44">[31]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlood199616_147-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlood199616-147">[117]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELockard200750_542-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELockard200750-542">[486]</a></sup> with diverse roots<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911_41-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENarayanan200911-41">[29]</a></sup> and no single founder.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEOsborne20059_543-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEOsborne20059-543">[487]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-548"><a href="#cite_note-548">[note 34]</a></sup>
</p><p>The history of Hinduism is often divided into periods of development. The first period is the pre-Vedic period, which includes the Indus Valley Civilization and local pre-historic religions, ending at about 1750 BCE. This period was followed in northern India by the Vedic period, which saw the introduction of the <a href="/wiki/Historical_Vedic_religion" title="Historical Vedic religion">historical Vedic religion</a> with the <a href="/wiki/Indo-Aryan_migrations" title="Indo-Aryan migrations">Indo-Aryan migrations</a>, starting somewhere between 1900 BCE to 1400 BCE.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200432–36_549-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200432–36-549">[492]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-552"><a href="#cite_note-552">[note 35]</a></sup> The subsequent period, between 800 BCE and 200 BCE, is "a turning point between the Vedic religion and Hindu religions",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels200438_553-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels200438-553">[495]</a></sup> and a formative period for Hinduism, Jainism and Buddhism. The Epic and Early Puranic period, from c. 200 BCE to 500 CE, saw the classical "Golden Age" of Hinduism (c. 320-650 CE), which coincides with the <a href="/wiki/Gupta_Empire" title="Gupta Empire">Gupta Empire</a>. In this period the six branches of Hindu philosophy evolved, namely <a href="/wiki/Samkhya" title="Samkhya">Samkhya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Yoga_(philosophy)" title="Yoga (philosophy)">Yoga</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nyaya" title="Nyaya">Nyaya</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vaisheshika" title="Vaisheshika">Vaisheshika</a>, <a href="/wiki/M%C4%ABm%C4%81%E1%B9%83s%C4%81" title="Mīmāṃsā">Mīmāṃsā</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Vedanta" title="Vedanta">Vedanta</a>. Monotheistic sects like <a href="/wiki/Shaivism" title="Shaivism">Shaivism</a> and <a href="/wiki/Vaishnavism" title="Vaishnavism">Vaishnavism</a> developed during this same period through the <a href="/wiki/Bhakti_movement" title="Bhakti movement">Bhakti movement</a>. The period from roughly 650 to 1100 CE forms the late Classical period<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004_23-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMichaels2004-23">[16]</a></sup> or early Middle Ages, in which classical Puranic Hinduism is established, and <a href="/wiki/Adi_Shankara" title="Adi Shankara">Adi Shankara</a>'s influential consolidation of <a href="/wiki/Advaita_Vedanta" title="Advaita Vedanta">Advaita Vedanta</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-554"><a href="#cite_note-554">[496]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shore_temple,_mahabalipuram.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1200" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="330" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg/220px-Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg/330px-Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/40/Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg/440px-Shore_temple%2C_mahabalipuram.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shore_temple,_mahabalipuram.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The Hindu <a href="/wiki/Shore_Temple" title="Shore Temple">Shore Temple</a> at <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mahabalipuram" title="Mahabalipuram">Mahabalipuram</a> was built by <a href="/wiki/Narasimhavarman_II" title="Narasimhavarman II">Narasimhavarman II</a>.</div></div></div>
<p>Hinduism under both Hindu and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Islamic_rulers_in_South_Asia" title="Islamic rulers in South Asia">Islamic</a> rulers from <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1250–1750 <span title="Common Era">CE</span></span>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-555"><a href="#cite_note-555">[497]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-556"><a href="#cite_note-556">[498]</a></sup> saw the increasing prominence of the Bhakti movement, which remains influential today. The <a href="/wiki/Colonial_India" title="Colonial India">colonial period</a> saw the emergence of various <a href="/wiki/Hindu_reform_movements" title="Hindu reform movements">Hindu reform movements</a> partly inspired by western movements, such as <a href="/wiki/Unitarianism" title="Unitarianism">Unitarianism</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Theosophy_(Blavatskian)" title="Theosophy (Blavatskian)">Theosophy</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma200227_557-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma200227-557">[499]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_Nepal" title="Kingdom of Nepal">Kingdom of Nepal</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Unification_of_Nepal" title="Unification of Nepal">Unification of Nepal</a> by <a href="/wiki/Shah_dynasty" title="Shah dynasty">Shah dynasty</a> was accompanied by the Hinduization of the <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">state</a> and continued till the <abbr title="circa">c.</abbr><span style="white-space:nowrap;"> 1950s</span>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vir_1988_https://books.google.com/books?id=yEHODCDK-8kC&amp;pg=PA56_56_558-0"><a href="#cite_note-Vir_1988_https://books.google.com/books?id=yEHODCDK-8kC&amp;pg=PA56_56-558">[500]</a></sup><sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Verifiability" title="Wikipedia:Verifiability"><span title="The material near this tag failed verification of its source citation(s). (June 2022)">failed verification</span></a></i>]</sup> <a href="/wiki/Indian_people" title="Indian people">Indians</a> were hired as plantation labourers in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/British_colonial" title="British colonial">British colonies</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mauritius" title="Mauritius">Mauritius</a>, <a href="/wiki/Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Trinidad and Tobago">Trinidad and Tobago</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-559"><a href="#cite_note-559">[501]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a> in 1947 was along religious lines, with the <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">Republic of India</a> emerging with a Hindu majority.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma2003176–189Thapar1993239–241_560-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma2003176–189Thapar1993239–241-560">[502]</a></sup> During the 20th century, due to the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Non-resident_Indian_and_person_of_Indian_origin" title="Non-resident Indian and person of Indian origin">Indian diaspora</a>, Hindu minorities have formed in all continents, with the largest communities in absolute numbers in the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_States" title="Hinduism in the United States">United States</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-561"><a href="#cite_note-561">[503]</a></sup> and the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_Kingdom" title="Hinduism in the United Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-562"><a href="#cite_note-562">[504]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 20th–21st century, many missionary organizations such as <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/ISKCON" title="ISKCON">ISKCON</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Sathya_Sai_Organization" title="Sathya Sai Organization">Sathya Sai Organization</a>, <a href="/wiki/Vedanta_Society" title="Vedanta Society">Vedanta Society</a> and so on. have been influential in spreading the core culture of Hinduism outside India.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ty78_192-1"><a href="#cite_note-ty78-192">[note 23]</a></sup> There have also been an increase of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_identity" title="Hindu identity">Hindu identity</a> in politics, mostly in <a href="/wiki/India" title="India">India</a>, <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a> in the form of <a href="/wiki/Hindutva" title="Hindutva">Hindutva</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-563"><a href="#cite_note-563">[505]</a></sup> The revivalist movement was mainly started and encouraged by many organisations like <a href="/wiki/Rashtriya_Swayamsevak_Sangh" title="Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh">RSS</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/BJP" title="BJP">BJP</a> and other organisations of <a href="/wiki/Sangh_Parivar" title="Sangh Parivar">Sangh Parivar</a> in India, while there are also many <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu_nationalist_parties" title="Hindu nationalist parties">Hindu nationalist parties and organisations</a> such as <a href="/wiki/Shivsena_Nepal" title="Shivsena Nepal">Shivsena Nepal</a> and <a href="/wiki/Rastriya_Prajatantra_Party_Nepal" title="Rastriya Prajatantra Party Nepal">RPP</a> in <a href="/wiki/Nepal" title="Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="/wiki/HINDRAF" title="HINDRAF">HINDRAF</a> in <a href="/wiki/Malaysia" title="Malaysia">Malaysia</a>, etc.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-564"><a href="#cite_note-564">[506]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Vir_1988_https://books.google.com/books?id=yEHODCDK-8kC&amp;pg=PA56_56_558-1"><a href="#cite_note-Vir_1988_https://books.google.com/books?id=yEHODCDK-8kC&amp;pg=PA56_56-558">[500]</a></sup> In September 2021, the State of <a href="/wiki/Indians_in_the_New_York_City_metropolitan_area#Religion" title="Indians in the New York City metropolitan area">New Jersey</a> aligned with the World Hindu Council to declare October as Hindu Heritage Month.
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Demographics">Demographics</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">Hinduism by country</a></div>
<p>Hinduism is a major religion in India. Hinduism was followed by around 79.8% of the country's population of 1.21 billion (<a href="/wiki/2011_Census_of_India" title="2011 Census of India">2011 census</a>) (966 million adherents).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-565"><a href="#cite_note-565">[507]</a></sup> Other <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_by_country" title="Hinduism by country">significant populations</a> are found in Nepal (23 million), Bangladesh (15 million) and the <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">Indonesian</a> island of <a href="/wiki/Bali" title="Bali">Bali</a> (3.9 million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-bps_566-0"><a href="#cite_note-bps-566">[508]</a></sup> There is also a significant population of <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">Hindus</a> are also present in Pakistan (4 million).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-567"><a href="#cite_note-567">[509]</a></sup> The majority of the Vietnamese <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Cham_people" title="Cham people">Cham people</a> also follow Hinduism, with the largest proportion in <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Ninh_Thu%E1%BA%ADn_Province" title="Ninh Thuận Province">Ninh Thuận Province</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-568"><a href="#cite_note-568">[510]</a></sup> Hinduism is the <a href="/wiki/Growth_of_religion" title="Growth of religion">third fastest-growing religion</a> in the world after <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a> and <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a>, with a predicted growth rate of 34% between 2010 and 2050.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-569"><a href="#cite_note-569">[511]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="center"><div class="thumb tnone"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:702px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="263" data-file-width="512" decoding="async" height="360" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg/700px-Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg/1050px-Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/74/Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg/1400px-Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg.png 2x" width="700"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Countries_by_percentage_of_adherents_to_Hinduism.svg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Percentage of Hindus by country<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-prcpercent_570-0"><a href="#cite_note-prcpercent-570">[512]</a></sup></div></div></div></div>
<p>Countries with the greatest proportion of Hindus:
</p>
<ol><li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Nepal" title="Hinduism in Nepal"><img alt="" data-file-height="885" data-file-width="726" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Nepal.svg/12px-Flag_of_Nepal.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Nepal.svg/19px-Flag_of_Nepal.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Flag_of_Nepal.svg/25px-Flag_of_Nepal.svg.png 2x" width="12"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Nepal" title="Hinduism in Nepal">Nepal</a></span> – 81.3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-571"><a href="#cite_note-571">[513]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_India" title="Hinduism in India"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1350" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/23px-Flag_of_India.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/35px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/4/41/Flag_of_India.svg/45px-Flag_of_India.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_India" title="Hinduism in India">India</a></span> – 79.8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-572"><a href="#cite_note-572">[514]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Mauritius" title="Hinduism in Mauritius"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_Mauritius.svg/23px-Flag_of_Mauritius.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_Mauritius.svg/35px-Flag_of_Mauritius.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/77/Flag_of_Mauritius.svg/45px-Flag_of_Mauritius.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Mauritius" title="Hinduism in Mauritius">Mauritius</a></span> – 48.5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-573"><a href="#cite_note-573">[515]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Guyana" title="Hinduism in Guyana"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_Guyana.svg/23px-Flag_of_Guyana.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_Guyana.svg/35px-Flag_of_Guyana.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/99/Flag_of_Guyana.svg/46px-Flag_of_Guyana.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Guyana" title="Hinduism in Guyana">Guyana</a></span> – 28.4%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-574"><a href="#cite_note-574">[516]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Fiji" title="Hinduism in Fiji"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Fiji.svg/23px-Flag_of_Fiji.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Fiji.svg/35px-Flag_of_Fiji.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Flag_of_Fiji.svg/46px-Flag_of_Fiji.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Fiji" title="Hinduism in Fiji">Fiji</a></span> – 27.9%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-575"><a href="#cite_note-575">[517]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bhutan" title="Hinduism in Bhutan"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Flag_of_Bhutan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Bhutan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Flag_of_Bhutan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Bhutan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/91/Flag_of_Bhutan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Bhutan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bhutan" title="Hinduism in Bhutan">Bhutan</a></span> – 22.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-576"><a href="#cite_note-576">[518]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Suriname" title="Hinduism in Suriname"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Flag_of_Suriname.svg/23px-Flag_of_Suriname.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Flag_of_Suriname.svg/35px-Flag_of_Suriname.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/60/Flag_of_Suriname.svg/45px-Flag_of_Suriname.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Suriname" title="Hinduism in Suriname">Suriname</a></span> – 22.3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-577"><a href="#cite_note-577">[519]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Hinduism in Trinidad and Tobago"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="480" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Flag_of_Trinidad_and_Tobago.svg/23px-Flag_of_Trinidad_and_Tobago.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Flag_of_Trinidad_and_Tobago.svg/35px-Flag_of_Trinidad_and_Tobago.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Flag_of_Trinidad_and_Tobago.svg/46px-Flag_of_Trinidad_and_Tobago.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Trinidad_and_Tobago" title="Hinduism in Trinidad and Tobago">Trinidad and Tobago</a></span> – 18.2%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-578"><a href="#cite_note-578">[520]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Qatar" title="Hinduism in Qatar"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="550" data-file-width="1400" decoding="async" height="9" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flag_of_Qatar.svg/23px-Flag_of_Qatar.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flag_of_Qatar.svg/35px-Flag_of_Qatar.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/Flag_of_Qatar.svg/46px-Flag_of_Qatar.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Qatar" title="Hinduism in Qatar">Qatar</a></span> – 13.8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-579"><a href="#cite_note-579">[521]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Hinduism in Sri Lanka"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Flag_of_Sri_Lanka.svg/23px-Flag_of_Sri_Lanka.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Flag_of_Sri_Lanka.svg/35px-Flag_of_Sri_Lanka.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/11/Flag_of_Sri_Lanka.svg/46px-Flag_of_Sri_Lanka.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Sri_Lanka" title="Hinduism in Sri Lanka">Sri Lanka</a></span> – 12.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-580"><a href="#cite_note-580">[522]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bahrain" title="Hinduism in Bahrain"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="900" data-file-width="1500" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Bahrain.svg/23px-Flag_of_Bahrain.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Bahrain.svg/35px-Flag_of_Bahrain.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2c/Flag_of_Bahrain.svg/46px-Flag_of_Bahrain.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bahrain" title="Hinduism in Bahrain">Bahrain</a></span> – 9.8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-581"><a href="#cite_note-581">[523]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bangladesh" title="Hinduism in Bangladesh"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1000" decoding="async" height="14" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg/23px-Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg/35px-Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f9/Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg/46px-Flag_of_Bangladesh.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Bangladesh" title="Hinduism in Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a></span> – 8.5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-582"><a href="#cite_note-582">[524]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_R%C3%A9union" title="Hinduism in Réunion"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/23px-Flag_of_France.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/35px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/c/c3/Flag_of_France.svg/45px-Flag_of_France.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_R%C3%A9union" title="Hinduism in Réunion">Réunion</a></span> – 6.8%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-583"><a href="#cite_note-583">[note 36]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_Arab_Emirates" title="Hinduism in the United Arab Emirates"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/23px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/35px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cb/Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg/46px-Flag_of_the_United_Arab_Emirates.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_the_United_Arab_Emirates" title="Hinduism in the United Arab Emirates">United Arab Emirates</a></span> – 6.6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-584"><a href="#cite_note-584">[525]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Malaysia" title="Hinduism in Malaysia"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Flag_of_Malaysia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Malaysia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Flag_of_Malaysia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Malaysia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/66/Flag_of_Malaysia.svg/46px-Flag_of_Malaysia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Malaysia" title="Hinduism in Malaysia">Malaysia</a></span> – 6.3%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-cia.gov_585-0"><a href="#cite_note-cia.gov-585">[526]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Kuwait" title="Hinduism in Kuwait"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/23px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/35px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/aa/Flag_of_Kuwait.svg/46px-Flag_of_Kuwait.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Kuwait" title="Hinduism in Kuwait">Kuwait</a></span> – 6%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-586"><a href="#cite_note-586">[527]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Oman" title="Hinduism in Oman"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Flag_of_Oman.svg/23px-Flag_of_Oman.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Flag_of_Oman.svg/35px-Flag_of_Oman.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/Flag_of_Oman.svg/46px-Flag_of_Oman.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Oman" title="Hinduism in Oman">Oman</a></span> – 5.5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-587"><a href="#cite_note-587">[528]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Singapore" title="Hinduism in Singapore"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/23px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/35px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Flag_of_Singapore.svg/45px-Flag_of_Singapore.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Singapore" title="Hinduism in Singapore">Singapore</a></span> – 5%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-2010_census_Full_report_588-0"><a href="#cite_note-2010_census_Full_report-588">[529]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Flag_of_Indonesia.svg/23px-Flag_of_Indonesia.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Flag_of_Indonesia.svg/35px-Flag_of_Indonesia.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Flag_of_Indonesia.svg/45px-Flag_of_Indonesia.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Indonesia" title="Hinduism in Indonesia">Indonesia</a></span> – 3.86%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-589"><a href="#cite_note-589">[530]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_New_Zealand" title="Hinduism in New Zealand"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Flag_of_New_Zealand.svg/23px-Flag_of_New_Zealand.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Flag_of_New_Zealand.svg/35px-Flag_of_New_Zealand.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3e/Flag_of_New_Zealand.svg/46px-Flag_of_New_Zealand.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_New_Zealand" title="Hinduism in New Zealand">New Zealand</a></span> – 2.62%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-590"><a href="#cite_note-590">[531]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Seychelles" title="Hinduism in Seychelles"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="12" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Seychelles.svg/23px-Flag_of_Seychelles.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Seychelles.svg/35px-Flag_of_Seychelles.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fc/Flag_of_Seychelles.svg/46px-Flag_of_Seychelles.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Seychelles" title="Hinduism in Seychelles">Seychelles</a></span> – 2.4%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-591"><a href="#cite_note-591">[532]</a></sup></li>
<li><span class="nowrap"><span class="flagicon" style="display:inline-block;width:25px;text-align:center;"><a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Pakistan" title="Hinduism in Pakistan"><img alt="" class="thumbborder" data-file-height="600" data-file-width="900" decoding="async" height="15" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Flag_of_Pakistan.svg/23px-Flag_of_Pakistan.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Flag_of_Pakistan.svg/35px-Flag_of_Pakistan.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/32/Flag_of_Pakistan.svg/45px-Flag_of_Pakistan.svg.png 2x" width="23"/></a></span> <a href="/wiki/Hinduism_in_Pakistan" title="Hinduism in Pakistan">Pakistan</a></span> – 2.14%.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-592"><a href="#cite_note-592">[533]</a></sup></li></ol>
<p>Demographically, Hinduism is the <a href="/wiki/Major_religious_groups" title="Major religious groups">world's third largest religion</a>, after <a href="/wiki/Christianity" title="Christianity">Christianity</a> and <a href="/wiki/Islam" title="Islam">Islam</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-593"><a href="#cite_note-593">[534]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-594"><a href="#cite_note-594">[535]</a></sup>
</p>

</td>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Persecution_and_debates">Persecution and debates</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Persecution">Persecution</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Hindus" title="Persecution of Hindus">Persecution of Hindus</a></div>
<p><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Hindu" title="Hindu">Hindus</a> have experienced both historical <a href="/wiki/Religious_persecution" title="Religious persecution">religious persecution</a>, ongoing <a href="/wiki/Religious_persecution" title="Religious persecution">religious persecution</a> and <a href="/wiki/Social_system" title="Social system">systematic</a> violence. These occur in the form of <a href="/wiki/Forced_conversion#India" title="Forced conversion">forced conversions</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-596"><a href="#cite_note-596">[537]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-597"><a href="#cite_note-597">[538]</a></sup> documented <a href="/wiki/Massacre" title="Massacre">massacres</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-598"><a href="#cite_note-598">[539]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-599"><a href="#cite_note-599">[540]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-600"><a href="#cite_note-600">[541]</a></sup> demolition and desecration of <a href="/wiki/Hindu_temple" title="Hindu temple">temples</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-601"><a href="#cite_note-601">[542]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_602-0"><a href="#cite_note-:1-602">[543]</a></sup> Historic persecutions of <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">Hindus</a> happened under <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Muslim_conquest_of_India" title="Muslim conquest of India">Muslim rulers</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-:1_602-1"><a href="#cite_note-:1-602">[543]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-603"><a href="#cite_note-603">[544]</a></sup> and also by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Christian_Missionaries" title="Christian Missionaries">Christian Missionaries</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-604"><a href="#cite_note-604">[545]</a></sup> In the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Mughal_Period" title="Mughal Period">Mughal Period</a>, Hindus were forced to pay the <a href="/wiki/Jizya" title="Jizya">Jizya</a>. In <a href="/wiki/Goa" title="Goa">Goa</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Goa_Inquisition" title="Goa Inquisition">1560 inquisition</a> by <a href="/wiki/Portuguese_India" title="Portuguese India">Portuguese colonists</a> is also considered one of the most brutal <a href="/wiki/Persecution_of_Hindus" title="Persecution of Hindus">persecutions of Hindus</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-605"><a href="#cite_note-605">[546]</a></sup> Between 200,000 and one million people, including both Muslims and Hindus, were killed during the <a href="/wiki/Partition_of_India" title="Partition of India">Partition of India</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-606"><a href="#cite_note-606">[547]</a></sup> In modern times, <a href="/wiki/Hindus" title="Hindus">Hindus</a> face discrimination in many parts of the world and also face persecution and <a href="/wiki/Forced_conversion" title="Forced conversion">forced conversion</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-607"><a href="#cite_note-607">[548]</a></sup> in many countries, especially in <a href="/wiki/Pakistan" title="Pakistan">Pakistan</a>, <a href="/wiki/Bangladesh" title="Bangladesh">Bangladesh</a>, <a href="/wiki/Fiji" title="Fiji">Fiji</a> and others.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-608"><a href="#cite_note-608">[549]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-609"><a href="#cite_note-609">[550]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Conversion_debate">Conversion debate</span></h3>
<p>In the modern era, religious conversion from and to Hinduism has been a controversial subject. Some state the concept of missionary conversion, either way, is anathema to the precepts of Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindmr_610-0"><a href="#cite_note-arvindmr-610">[551]</a></sup>
</p><p>It is known that, unlike <a href="/wiki/Ethnic_religion" title="Ethnic religion">ethnic religions</a>, which exist almost exclusively among, for instance, the Japanese (<a href="/wiki/Shinto" title="Shinto">Shinto</a>), the Chinese (<a href="/wiki/Taoism" title="Taoism">Taoism</a>), or the Jews (<a href="/wiki/Judaism" title="Judaism">Judaism</a>), Hinduism in India and Nepal is widespread among many, both Indo-Aryan and non-Aryan ethnic groups. In addition, religious conversion to Hinduism has a long history outside India. Merchants and traders of India, particularly from the Indian peninsula, carried their religious ideas, which led to religious conversions to Hinduism outside India. In antiquity and the Middle Ages, Hinduism was the state religion in many kingdoms of Asia, the so-called <a href="/wiki/Greater_India" title="Greater India">Greater India</a>: from Afghanistan (Kabul) in the West and including almost all of <a href="/wiki/Southeast_Asia" title="Southeast Asia">Southeast Asia</a> in the East (Cambodia, Vietnam, Indonesia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Gonda_333-1"><a href="#cite_note-Gonda-333">[293]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-611"><a href="#cite_note-611">[552]</a></sup> Philippines), and only by 15th century was nearly everywhere supplanted by Buddhism and Islam.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECœdès1968Pande2006AcriCreeseGriffiths2011_330-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECœdès1968Pande2006AcriCreeseGriffiths2011-330">[290]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-spread_331-1"><a href="#cite_note-spread-331">[291]</a></sup> Therefore, it looks quite natural for the modern Hindu preaching in the world.
</p><p>Within India, archeological and textual evidence such as the 2nd-century BCE <a href="/wiki/Heliodorus_pillar" title="Heliodorus pillar">Heliodorus pillar</a> suggest that Greeks and other foreigners converted to Hinduism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESharma201284_612-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESharma201284-612">[553]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-613"><a href="#cite_note-613">[554]</a></sup> The debate on proselytization and religious conversion between Christianity, Islam and Hinduism is more recent, and started in the 19th century.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-rafiuddinahmed_614-0"><a href="#cite_note-rafiuddinahmed-614">[555]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-ayeshajalal_615-0"><a href="#cite_note-ayeshajalal-615">[556]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-620"><a href="#cite_note-620">[note 37]</a></sup>
</p><p>Religious leaders of some Hindu reform movements such as the <a href="/wiki/Arya_Samaj" title="Arya Samaj">Arya Samaj</a> launched <i><a href="/wiki/Shuddhi_(Hinduism)" title="Shuddhi (Hinduism)">Shuddhi</a></i> movement to proselytize and reconvert Muslims and Christians back to Hinduism,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-csadcock_619-1"><a href="#cite_note-csadcock-619">[560]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-621"><a href="#cite_note-621">[561]</a></sup> while those such as the <a href="/wiki/Brahmo_Samaj" title="Brahmo Samaj">Brahmo Samaj</a> suggested Hinduism to be a non-missionary religion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindmr_610-1"><a href="#cite_note-arvindmr-610">[551]</a></sup> All these sects of Hinduism have welcomed new members to their group, while other leaders of Hinduism's diverse schools have stated that given the intensive proselytization activities from missionary Islam and Christianity, this "there is no such thing as proselytism in Hinduism" view must be re-examined.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-arvindmr_610-2"><a href="#cite_note-arvindmr-610">[551]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-csadcock_619-2"><a href="#cite_note-csadcock-619">[560]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-622"><a href="#cite_note-622">[562]</a></sup>
</p><p>The appropriateness of conversion from major religions to Hinduism, and vice versa, has been and remains an actively debated topic in India, Nepal,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKim,_Sebastian20051–29_623-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKim,_Sebastian20051–29-623">[563]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-624"><a href="#cite_note-624">[564]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-625"><a href="#cite_note-625">[565]</a></sup> and in Indonesia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-626"><a href="#cite_note-626">[566]</a></sup>
</p>
